4. Adobe Target: Part of the Adobe Experience Cloud suite, it offers advanced testing and personalization features.

5. Crazy Egg: Focuses on visual analytics with heatmaps, scroll maps, and click tracking.

[21.10.23, 13:24:34] ~â€¯Mikael: Sure bro. Im glad to hear more. Im open to switch if its better.
[21.10.23, 13:51:05] ~â€¯E.: Sure, I'll simplify that for you. Hyros uses a Chrome extension that adds a layer to your ads manager. This layer displays the conversions for a specific campaign, which is what they mean by sending the data back to the Ads Manager.

In contrast, we send data back to the ad platform in order to match conversions with a specific profile and attribute the conversion to a campaign the profile previously clicked on. This process doesn't need a Chrome extension. This approach is more effective because it helps the ad platform target the right audience by narrowing down your broad audience, as they will have a better understanding of who your audience actually is.

[21.10.23, 14:03:08] ~â€¯Mikael: Hyros uses chrome extension to show the correct data. But they also use hyros pixel and data to send back data to the meta pixel. Also i am using hyros pixel which is suppose to work better
[21.10.23, 14:12:16] ~â€¯E.: I understand. If you disable the Chrome extension for a moment and observe what the ad platform records for conversions, you can determine if the data sent directly to the ad platform is accurate. What your ads manager displays without the extension is essentially what the ad platform knows. Without this data, the ad platform would be targeting blindly.

[31.10.23, 11:53:36] ~â€¯David B: If you're struggling with email. Here's my suggested list of email flows. 

Email Marketing Systems 

Automation Flows

1. Pop-Up Flow - 3 emails
2. Lead Quiz Flow - 3 emails 
3. Cart Abandonment Flow - 2 emails 
4. Browse Abandonment Flow - 2 emails 
5. Post Purchase - 5 emails
6. Re-Order or Predictive AI Flow - 3 emails 
7. Thank You Flow (Customers that purchased the 2nd Time) - 3 emails
8. Reward Flow - 3 emails
9. Upsell + Cross-sells - 2 emails
10. Birthday Flow - 2 emails
11. VIP Flow - 2 emails
12. Win-Back Flow - 3 emails (Then clean list)
13. New Release Flow - 3 emails

[5.11.23, 13:12:36] ~â€¯Marko: Be aware of confirmation bias. This is so common. If you mention any problem (sudden drop in conversation rate, high cpmâ€™s or anything else) you will always find people that are experiencing the same thing in groups like these and it will seem as if itâ€™s something everyone is experiencing. In a group with 170 people, at any given time you will easily find 5-10 people that are experiencing something similar to you, and of course they will respond when you mention your problem.

[8.11.23, 20:45:08] ~â€¯Natasha Iris: Hey guys, with the holiday season upon us, itâ€™s important to not only make sales but also ensure that you are managing fraud and risk; particularly in international markets!

Did you know?

Across all merchants that dispute a chargeback, only 20% of the time they win the dispute. 

With the customer and the issuing banks having final say, once the chargeback is accepted, the disputed amount is returned to the cardholder and the merchant also incurs additional fees, normally $25 per chargeback.

[16.11.23, 19:34:34] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: You can -  you are just going to pay a lot more in credit card fees and have false declines.  

As you scale, you will want to leverage the entity in the US and process locally through it to eliminate 2-3% in cross border / currency conversion fees.

This will also help eliminate false declines by processing US customer transactions through your US entity vs. EU entity.  On average you will see a 8-10% (or more) increase in auth rates which has a direct line impact to your conversions.

[16.11.23, 21:15:40] ~â€¯Natasha Iris: Being in the online review space for 4yrs I can say do not buy reviews. Itâ€™s actually against policy and if they see itâ€™s paid for, reviews get removed and youâ€™re back to where you started , star rating wise. 

Iâ€™d recommend organic pushing to your customers. I.e giving discount codes in packages for leaving reviews, disputing old negative reviews with trustpilot to get them removed. And reaching out to past customers who left negative reviews that you resolved issues with. Asking them to change their star rating and update their review. 

Reviews are a long play, but the goal is atleast 3.7 + star rating, we see have more customer sales. And positive impression on potential cust. 


Hope that helps! â€<This message was edited>

27 Ways to Increase Funnel Conversions:

[18.11.23, 8:02:14] ~â€¯Luka: Generally same product works best. Is it a giftable product? What we did was on our upsell we sold the same product and also gave a free gift with the upsell. We added a red bowtie on the image (product + packaging) and it helped boost our upsell take rate, even getting people to buy 2 more instead of just 1 more.

Few things that come to mind..

- What platform are you running on?
- Did you try modeling how other successful upsells are done? (Even using terms like" "One-Time Offer", timer, really good value offer (big discount, free shipping, etc) ?
- You may need a bit of a longer-form upsell page (or video) if you need to build the perceived value & justify the price. Think reviews, benefits section etc instead of just a typical short-form 1 section upsell page

[24.11.23, 4:25:02] ~â€¯Y: create two workflow automations (funnel or global ones), one triggered by optins/purchase attempts, and then adds to list in Klaviyo (a Leads list).

Another, triggered by purchases, and it adds to another list in Klaviyo (a purchases list).

Now in klaviyo (if havent already) make a flow automation, that is triggered when a customer is added to the leads list, and wait 30mins or so, then check if they are in buyers list. that's how to do abandoned cart. 

Welcome series is easy, just trigger it whenever someone is added to the buyers list.

[5.12.23, 12:21:02] ~â€¯Malik: Something must be happening with Funnelish and Stripe. All year almost no failed payements and now I have some each days. In different markets
[5.12.23, 12:21:49] ~â€¯RS: Do you have EU stripe?
[5.12.23, 12:26:23] ~â€¯Malik: Yes
[5.12.23, 12:32:02] ~â€¯RS: I have EU stripe and I have payment declines every day for 4 years already. Some days more, some days less. USA payments are declined most often. It is USA banks declining the card for security purposes because if you have EU stripe, it is an international payment. In these cases we always tell in Tidio chat customers to call their bank, or we send email explaining why card was declined, and ask to call their bank. 30-50% of the people actually call their bank and after that they can successfully place the order. UJ payments are declined very rarely but they still occur. Also for UK payments customers need to call their bank. 
New Zealand payments are never declined. Australia payments are declined very rarely. 

Also, check in stripe what is the cause of decline. Maybe it is not a bank decline, but maybe it is because customers cannot complete the 3DS Secure authentification asked by their bank. 
And in funnelish it often happens for UK customers (same if you target EU countries).
[5.12.23, 12:34:34] ~â€¯RS: Also, I had my payments declined in sholify very often since one page checkout came out. I then switched off address autocomplete in checkout, so customers need to enter their Shipping address manually. It reduced decline rate by 80-90% instantly. 
Also, in funnelish I dont have address auto-completion. And above the payment field I inform customers to not use card detail auto-fill. I ask them to manually enter card details. Auto-filling card details Also can cause declines.
[5.12.23, 12:35:57] ~â€¯RS: Now, I still have 2-5 payments declines every day doing 6-8k/day but Im Okay with that.
[5.12.23, 13:19:50] ~â€¯Jeremy Leppink: Good tips, thanks

Other than that its only stripe, checkout.com and mollie

[6.12.23, 15:02:59] ~â€¯Luka: Not sure about France specifically, but we sell in Asia in a country that's filled with low quality sellers & a lot of people hesitant to shop anywhere outside the local Amazon equivalent. Here's how we solved it. Some are less powerful, some more:

- Real user reviews (not UGC reviews). But boring old low quality camera reviews from REAL customers
- 100% unique assets (website, videos, imagery, custom 3D animations, custom 2-3 minute sales video where we interview 2 people & their experience etc)
- Real, verified reviews
- Good quality IG with reviews in your highlights, custom imagery etc
- Legit social proof. Pay for news listings rather than just putting a fake quote. People google and verify it.
- Make the offer really good (bonuses, free shipping, returns, money-back guarantee etc)
- 100% custom filmed ads, no stealing content (they've already seen it)
- If it makes sense, show the label of your product. Highlight reviews where the photo contains a label of your brand

For example, https://purple.com/purple-grid right away you know this brand is legit cause of it's websites, high quality assets, high perceived value, tons of verified reviews etc.
[6.12.23, 15:04:01] ~â€¯Luka: In your live recordings of your website, when there is a person doing nothing for a few minutes, often times they're Googling your brand - have that covered too
[6.12.23, 15:05:49] ~â€¯Luka: Even smaller things... like if you have a security certificate, make it clickable (with a popup to prevent them them leaving) showing the certificate, and stuff like that. These are small things but 5 small things that add 3% boost in sales each, is already a +15% boost in your conversion rate.

[8.12.23, 0:41:17] ~â€¯RS: Does anyone know what may cause misrepresentation on Google Merchant Centre?

Iâ€™ve gone through the website and Google account many times and still canâ€™t find what causes that. I have appealed many times already with no success.

The name of the business in Merchant Centre matches the name of the website, contact information provided in the footer and on the contact us page, privacy policy, t&c, shipping policy, refund/return policy, FAQs, full company information, and VAT. High-quality designed website, SSL certificate, and products are synced from Shopify with Google Merchant Centre, including valid GTIN numbers and full information.



Where to look? It should be something really simple, as they finish the appeal within a few hours, informing them that they still found misrepresentation.

[19.01.24, 8:53:38] ~â€¯Faizan: Hey bro, we just recently switched over our Shopify payments from Ca to Us region. It was fairly simple. Just had to contact them and follow up on the matter frequently. They did need a US address & SSN. We just said we moved to the US, have an LLC & residence and would like to switch to US Shopify payments to save on currency conversion fee. They will then guide you to reset your Shopify payments account or manually do it and you can set it up again with the US info. 

First step was deactivate SP, then update the store address and details with your US info, then set up SP again, at which point it should prompt you to enter all details again. (Enter US info). If all is good it will activate and no issues, if they do need additional info theyâ€™ll reach out.
[19.01.24, 9:15:23] ~â€¯Matteo Pellegrini: Thanks for your reply bro,

[2.02.24, 18:04:08] Radek: My piece of advise would be to split test the price. 

I know it doesnâ€™t sound like directly related to the CPMs, but if you run conversion campaign and your pricing is more expensive than realistically perceived value, fb need to target specific (premium segment) people in order to get that conversion, which effectively narrows down the pool of buyers and thus higher CPM. 

Itâ€™s just my hypothesis but this experiment helped my brand to get down even to $10CPM in US and overall better funnel metrics.
[2.02.24, 18:27:50] ~â€¯Eric R: Great point about split testing pricing. How much lower did you drop the price to see these better results?
[2.02.24, 18:33:20] ~â€¯David B: Also consider split testing the price higher. 

Higher price higher perceived quality. 

Several brands I've worked with have seen an increase in sales when they have raised their price. 

One brand increased by over $30 per unit and the higher the price the more they sold. â€<This message was edited>
[2.02.24, 18:54:33] ~â€¯Kamal: Damn definitely need to try that

[2.02.24, 18:56:08] Radek: For us it was 20% drop, but I am sure it is very specific to the niche, product uniqueness and other factors that influence the perceived value.

[5.02.24, 11:56:54] ~â€¯Santi Roa: Sometimes it can be a unique advantage for your company, sometimes you can't delegate that huge part of the biz to a bunch of different 3pls

[5.02.24, 11:57:22] ~â€¯Santi Roa: I experienced that recently
[5.02.24, 11:57:36] ~â€¯Santi Roa: Growing from 300k/800k a month to over 2.5m/month
[5.02.24, 11:58:30] ~â€¯Santi Roa: Small issues scale fast, and if you don't control them, it's super hard to improve and solve problems. Mostly when these things take time and involve physical flows of things.

[5.02.24, 11:59:46] ~â€¯Santi Roa: I'm seeing something like that now with international sales, Amazon, trying to get to retail distribution, growing skus, needing personalization and more custom shit 3pls don't do (for example analyzing defective returns and provide a report for my product design team)
[5.02.24, 12:02:24] ~â€¯Santi Roa: After you get some scale, flexibility decreases and everything takes months to plan.

Another example: a rebranding

Before, I thought it was just coming up with a new logo and colors for the brand... now it evolved into doing a professional customer research (not DIY), working on the brand persona, voice, etc. Then after finding and having the right logo and colors, redesign all packaging and manufacture that.

Manufacturing takes 45days + 30days sea freight to the US.

But I also need to handle inventory leftouts with old branding
[5.02.24, 12:03:29] ~â€¯Santi Roa: So everything becomes more complex as you scale, and that's when you might consider bringing those things that are not core to your biz now, inhouse, for strategic reasons.

But don't do it to be cheap and save a few bucks (I made that mistake having everything inhouse then nothing had my attention)
[5.02.24, 12:04:08] ~â€¯Santi Roa: I hope this gives perspective, and I wish I heard this a year ago.

[21.02.24, 12:28:52] ~â€¯David B: You need to edit advertorials ruthlessly, especially for mobile view. 

If a sentence isn't adding value or moving the story along, cut it. 

Long-form advertorials can be very effective if the audience is prepared for it through the ads. 

Another option is to change an advertorial into a VSL. VSLs are lower friction and require less effort so they are more likely to be watched. 

Check your heat maps and see how much of your advertorial is being read if you see a drop off at a certain point, it needs to be reworked.

[23.02.24, 22:43:23] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: If UK entity selling to EU customer likely 2 (or more) out of every 10 customers will false decline because you are selling cross border.  The issuing bank will flag it as fraud even if customer has funds because they are now interacting with a business outside of their domestic footprint.  They will need to call their bank to authorize transaction or use a bank transfer payment option where they push funds to you.
[23.02.24, 22:44:48] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: Reason codes can vary depending on issuing bank - most banks just label it as â€˜declineâ€™ which is a sign that it is a cross border transaction and likely a false decline. [2.05.24, 18:27:51] ~â€¯Thomas Tran: we experience it since last year. Any solution from your clients?
[2.05.24, 18:48:18] Topi: - Enough skill (basic level animation)
- Attitude (not give up / complain even lots of revisions in the beginning)
- Is proud of their work (this makes them being precise)

Other than that
- Some level of creativity
- Common sense
- Speed (comes usually with time)
[2.05.24, 18:52:36] Topi: If they donâ€™t have the skills, VSL gets never done no matter how hard they try and your time (or team members time) goes into teaching / advicing. If they bitch even once during the first sets of revisions which are usually big because theyre just adapting into your style and process, they are not good. Same goes if they just care about getting the video done fast and pay. The best editors we found really care what they send to us and therefore they improve rapidly when they see what our senior editors do.
[2.05.24, 18:54:27] Topi: Not fast to find good editors, you have to test a lot. Bulk interview and have them do samples before using too much time into talking with them. Create a sheet that includes all payments etc explained so you can send it out for everyone at once.
[2.05.24, 18:54:52] Topi: Once you find good ones, ask if they have friends, usually they do as they are sharing info and thats how you get better than average leads

[6.05.24, 20:19:19] ~â€¯Maxi: Cant be just said like that.

Our checkout purchase rate is around 9.8%

This always depends where your traffic is from, what kind of creatives (image or video) 

and mainly if you show the price on lander or not.

If you show the price on your landers for example, the checkout purchase rate should go up to 30-40% but then your CTR on landing page will drop.

There will always be a tradeoff, especially with an $100+ front end price

[7.05.24, 9:26:50] RenÃ© Crooijmans: 1. You would have to make a duplicate of your current checkout and re-add all of your products there with the updated pricing
2. â Then you duplicate your landing page. You send 50% of the traffic to the old landing page and 50% to the new one. On this new landing page, you change the action for pressing a button from â€œnext stepâ€ to â€œgo to URLâ€. For the URL, you would put the URL of your new checkout with updated prices

[10.05.24, 0:30:43] â€ª+47Â 973Â 16Â 810â€¬: We have this at least once every 2 or 3 days. We used to have it daily, but what causes this in the checkout is double payment method element. If you have product element, or payment method element double for some reason (such as one that is responsive for desktop, and one for the phone, this causes double-orders). 

We had this on our upsells too, and once we removed the duplicate, we never had it again.

We still have people place an order, arrive on Upsell #1, click the "back" button their browser, and place the order again, but to circumvent this we put a little disclaimer at the top, urging the person to NOT press the back button, as this may cause them to place a double-order. 

Unfortunately, besides the above, I have found nothing more to help, and customers will always be customers, I just had to eat the loss on the shipped products and CPA, when customers e-mail us regarding wanting to remove the excess item or items from their order, as sometimes they do this up to 6-7+ times, over and over, thinking it did not work the first 6 times....

[13.05.24, 18:16:18] ~â€¯L: Hey everyone, I'm thinking of moving my store from the UK to the US. Right now, I'm running ads from an account set on UK time. Do you think it could mess with performance if the ads are delivered in UK time instead of US time?
[13.05.24, 18:31:21] ~â€¯Ignasi: No. Itâ€™s fine
[13.05.24, 19:04:57] ~â€¯L: â€This message was deleted.
[13.05.24, 19:05:14] ~â€¯L: Thank you. Have you had any experience with this? Are there any considerations I should be aware of when the country and ad account have mismatched time zones?
[13.05.24, 19:09:45] ~â€¯Ignasi: Yes. Quite a lot of experience. Having accounts with different time-zones and using an attribution tool like Hyros (canâ€™t speak for the others) messes things up badly as Hyros can only work with one time zone, so you get unreliable attribution data.

If you still want to do it, you can solve reporting of diff time-zone accounts in ads reporting in meta which works really well, and you can chose 1-day, 7-day etc attribution so long as you select more than one account (and save your Hyros money for other stuff)

From my experience running everything in your time zone is so much easier for you, and youâ€™ll see that Facebook will pace spending during day/night of the time zone your campaign is targeting. So in the morning Europe will be spending a lot, and the US will be asleep spending close to nothing.
[13.05.24, 19:21:25] ~â€¯L: Ok great thank you very much!

So nothing to be worried about Ad delivery, Facebook will basically take care of it.
I should only expect some mismatch on the attributions tool because of the different timezone, correct?
Thank you again ğŸ‘ğŸ»
[13.05.24, 20:18:02] ~â€¯Alessandro Sassi: Should be 4%
[13.05.24, 20:45:37] ~â€¯Ignasi: Yes if you use 2 accounts with different time zones and a 3rd party tool for attribution that doesnâ€™t have multiple time zones like hyros

[21.05.24, 14:30:07] ~â€¯Sonu Duhra: Hi guys, whats the main difference between advertorial and VSL in terms of the Framework?
[21.05.24, 14:34:22] ~â€¯David B: The frameworks overlap quite a lot. And you should apply the same principles. The biggest difference is you need to signpost an advertorial much more with good subheadings and headlines. People rarely read an advertorial from top to bottom. They check the headline to make sure they're in the right place, then skip to the part of most interest to them. 

People don't usually skip to different points in a VSL so your hook and lead need to be very strong and call out a big pain point and open a loop to keep the engagement there.
[21.05.24, 14:36:18] ~â€¯Sonu Duhra: Ok nice thanks

[25.05.24, 22:40:23] ~â€¯Yusuf Business: buying fb profiles from sellers never worked for me actually, buying from family & friends work perfectly well, never had issues â€<This message was edited>
[25.05.24, 22:44:37] ~â€¯Yusuf Business: I donâ€™t buy new laptop.

When I buy a profile from someone I know, I get their FB profile, email connected to FB and passport photo (in case FB asks for id proof at some point)

They need to log out of their profiles from everywhere. 

Then I wait 2-3 days to login their profile. This is needed especially if youâ€™re located in different country than the person you bought from. I login from my computer.

If your profile is banned on your computer, I suggest opening new user, it works as new computer on FB eyes.

When you first login to profile, donâ€™t try to change security settings such as 2 fac authentication, password, etc. The profile can get blocked

First two weeks, I warm them up by engaging with 10 posts a day, sending messages to other fb profiles (usually the ones my team or me control)

Only then I change security settings, add to ad accounts, never had issues with this structure. My team members implement the same steps if their profiles get banned at some point â€<This message was edited>
[25.05.24, 23:25:48] ~â€¯Gedion: Hadnâ€™t had any problems regarding using different IP adress for the same profile?

[27.05.24, 18:22:17] ~â€¯Wouter Akika: When getting payment processors you need a few levels of negotiation

1. Payout frequency (Daily is best)
2. Payout Times (T+1 is best, means next day payout)
3. Fixed Reserve (You want this to be 0)
4. Rolling Reserve (You want this to be 0)
5. Underwriting / Instant access (You want underwriting to happen, stripe does not underwrite and that's why you get fucked in the ass, they never did due diligence so they pull the plug the moment you get any disputes / sales increase)
6. Interchange + X (go for 0.1-0.4%)
7. Price per transaction (go for 0.05-0.15 max)

[27.05.24, 21:09:54] â€ª+41Â 75Â 418Â 01Â 39â€¬: Steps to Easily Extract Post IDs:

Navigate to the ads level in Facebook Ads Manager.
Select and preview the ad with the highest number of Facebook comments, then open it.
Click on the post's date, which is clickable.
From the URL, copy the "pfbid" (e.g., facebook.com/brand_name/posts/pfbid13s..............).
Reuse the extracted post ID.

[28.05.24, 10:42:57] ~â€¯Matteo Pellegrini: Hey guys curious to know your creative process for analyse part,

I'm currently improving the analysis part

We test over 500 ads a week, here is our actual process:
- We currently report the new winners on a sheet every week
- the good winners we set up a fake comment process under the ad (Facebook only)
- then we dispatch to the creative department to create ad level, translation etc.
- we analyze what worked and what didn't so we can learn from it

Curious about your process?

[7.06.24, 18:42:50] ~â€¯Mikael: whats card testing bots?
[7.06.24, 18:47:20] â€ª+41Â 75Â 418Â 01Â 39â€¬: how to avoid?
[7.06.24, 18:47:36] ~â€¯Y: Fraudsters use your stripe page to test stolen card numbers until the find the right cvc number! Usually they send thousands of requests on short period of time and itâ€™s hard to see them as stripe doesnâ€™t show failed api calls except under developer logs
[7.06.24, 18:49:37] ~â€¯Mikael: can you see this in transactions? Because there arnt any transactions showing this
[7.06.24, 18:50:03] â€ª+41Â 75Â 418Â 01Â 39â€¬: I think I am seing something exactly like this through shopify payments currently is there a way to avoid this?
[7.06.24, 18:50:39] ~â€¯Y: https://support.stripe.com/questions/how-do-i-prevent-card-testing-attacks?locale=en-GB

In the past weve seen these in our platform then we had to implement rate limiting and some verifications to prevent them, 

If you are seeing that issue then you could add captcha using cloudflare to your domain, or simply contact the platform to stop it, itâ€™s the responsibility of the platform
[7.06.24, 18:51:15] ~â€¯Y: Weird ğŸ˜ i think shopify might have good filters against them but in case it doesnâ€™t get to their support when you see that happening
[7.06.24, 18:53:17] ~â€¯Y: Go to developers > logs thatâ€™s the only place to see them then filter by failed POST requests.

If you are using funnelish, itâ€™s easy to detect, just pay attention to any sudden spikes in purchase attempts, usually the attack lasts 20mins max!
[7.06.24, 18:55:09] ~â€¯Y: The good news is, if stripe had banned you in the past due to this (they will not tell/confirm to you , you will have to find out yourself!

[11.06.24, 13:21:32] ~â€¯Santi Roa: What volume are you doing with this fluctuations?
[11.06.24, 13:25:54] ~â€¯Santi Roa: It's super common, but you should aim to close that gap between great days and bad days. I believe it can be different things
1) Competition. If you are in a very competitive niche with lots of competitors, and everyone is doing kinda the same thing, it can be part of why this happens.

2) Media buying strategy: you might have a non solid strategy that's messing up the algorithm by changing too many things, or bidding for the same people accross accounts/campaigns

3) Creatives and offer: if this is not good enough, you might have days where Fb can reach the ideal audience that matches your creatives and days that they don't. For this, you should diversify angles/creative styles, actor demographics, etc

[14.06.24, 21:08:21] ~â€¯David B: Congrats! You won't have any data yet so you have a couple of choices I like.

[14.06.24, 21:09:08] ~â€¯Mukhtar: Send the video editor a test to edit a 90-second video. Just provide them with 1 or 2 inspiration videos and very minimal details. 

This task will make it very clear how creative they are and how you would be dealing with them in the future.

Then pick the top ones, do interviews, and send out a second test. 

This time, pay them for the test and provide instructions to edit the full video.
[14.06.24, 21:10:21] ~â€¯David B: I'd be looking for pace, smooth transitions, speed, communication, and creativity. 

Personally, I always pay people for test. Time isn't free but everyone operates in their own way. Hope that helps.

[18.06.24, 19:57:10] ~â€¯Yusuf: from what i know yes you dont pay income tax in uae but imo they can introduce income tax in near future

[18.06.24, 20:02:37] ~â€¯Kim Romanov: Iâ€™m not looking for a way to avoid taxes. I hope to pay around 20% to get my money and live in a nice place. There was so-called Beckham Tax Law in Spain, that fixes 24% personal income tax for overseas incomes but in this case I think Iâ€™ll also pay a corporative tax in the US. 
Iâ€™m looking for someone who lives in Spain or Dubai now and knows for sure
[18.06.24, 20:15:55] ~â€¯Yusuf: Again, just will share my idea, someone from spain can answer better, hope this helps

Beckham law has criterias, one of them is not owning more than 25% of a company that you're getting payments from (if you give ownership to someone else, this could work)

but doing beckham law with single member US LLC is tricky because US LLC is disregarded entity by default (you can setup tax structure as c corp and pay corporate taxes to US)

For disregarded entity, whatever it makes, it goes directly to owner and owner is responsible for paying income taxes wherever they are registered, so technically you will not only responsible for the money you bring to spain but will be responsible for total profit you make from your company

if it's not single member llc, then it automatically needs to pay corporate taxes in the US
[18.06.24, 20:35:25] ~â€¯Ignasi: Theyâ€™re working on an MbappÃ© law in the community of Madrid but I believe it hasnâ€™t passed yet. It will almost certainly pass if it hasnâ€™t already. Itâ€™s similar to Beckhamâ€™s but applies to residents of Madrid. You can fix your legal address there and live elsewhere in Spain

[2.07.24, 4:29:53] â€ª+7Â 985Â 367â€‘53â€‘18â€¬: Yes, it does. Do a test: add a cloaker to the pages that are in the subsequent stages of the funnel. When launching a campaign, even before the ad is approved, you will already be able to see many Facebook user agents on the pages that are ahead
[2.07.24, 4:35:58] â€ª+7Â 985Â 367â€‘53â€‘18â€¬: But I think using a less agressive lander can indeed offer some advantages. Itâ€™s not just that Facebook might have difficulty crawling the subsequent page, but it also strategically manages the flow of user interaction. A lander can soften the initial impact of aggressive copywriting. If an aggressive copy were placed directly on the next page, it could immediately raise flags within Facebook's review system, as their crawlers and algorithms are designed to detect and flag such content early on. However, by placing a more neutral or compliant copy on the lander, you reduce the likelihood of triggering Facebook's scrutiny at the first touchpoint. Furthermore, from a psychological perspective, users who encounter aggressive marketing messages on the second page are more likely to perceive it as part of your website rather than associating it directly with Facebook â€<This message was edited>
[2.07.24, 5:18:45] ~â€¯Yusuf: anyone in bali? organizing dinner with some other successful ecom guys

[12.07.24, 23:01:37] ~â€¯Kim Romanov: Hi everyone,

Does anyone have experience switching Shopify Payments from Canada (or another country) to the US?

I'm currently waiting for the EIN for my new US-based LLC and have requested to switch from Canadian Shopify Payments to US through support. They have asked me to provide proof of operational presence in the US.

Here's the email I received from Shopify:

---

Hi there,

Kait here from the Merchant Verification team at Shopify. We understand that you are looking to use Shopify Payments United States. In order to make this change successfully, we require some information. Can you please describe what kind of business operations you currently have in the United States?

Shopify has to follow regulatory and contractual obligations which require that we only provide financial services to merchants who are physically located in a supported region. Shopifyâ€™s standards for this requirement mean that registering your business in the region and obtaining a bank account is not enough.

To be eligible for Shopify Payments, you must meet one of the following criteria:

- If you are a Sole Proprietor, the business owner must personally live in the country.
- If you are a Company, LLC, or similar business type, you must be registered with the government of that country and also be able to provide evidence of substantial operations physically happening there.

If you believe your business meets these requirements, please reply here with a detailed description of your operations in the United States.

Some examples of operational presence could include (but are not limited to): You rent or own warehouse space and ship your orders from there, you have an office there with employees consistently occupying the space, or you have retail location(s) there. You may have other examples of operations you have in the country which youâ€™d like to provide: If you can respond with as much detail as possible, that is helpful for our review.

If you operate the business entirely from outside of the United States, you can confirm this also.

Please only provide written details and do not send documents over email - if we require documents to confirm these details, we will provide you with a secure portal to upload them.

Your payouts will be paused until this review is completed.

---

Has anyone gone through this process or have advice on how to provide the required information?

Thanks!

[15.07.24, 19:08:23] China Bigboss: try todoist make digital if you are not on digital try covey matrix
[15.07.24, 19:10:20] ~â€¯David B: @â¨~Jonathan Lindbergâ© It sounds like you're already doing much better than most...

But this is a high performance group! ğŸ’ª 

You might want to look into *time boxing* to avoid Parkinson's Law...

Parkinson's Law is the idea that work expands to fill whatever time you give it. 

Without a time limit, it will just keep going. 
 
Instead of: todo - write a Full VSL...  

Try: write a full VSL - 2 hours - 9am-11am.

This is insanely effective. 

Hope that helps. 

@â¨China Bigbossâ© makes a great suggestion too. Covey Matrix helps you realise how much sh*t you are doing that should be completely removed or delegated.
[15.07.24, 19:12:08] ~â€¯Jonathan Lindberg: @â¨~David Bâ© @â¨China Bigbossâ© Thanks for the tips, will definitely be trying this!
[15.07.24, 19:13:51] ~â€¯David B: I write over 210 emails per month across 8 different ecom brands. It would be impossible without deep work and time boxing.

Basically when choosing IP firms, we have 2 brackets

B) Hire a local firm specific to our country

Feedback score is a metric, not a problem. Youâ€™re getting measured on how good youâ€™re doing as a company/brand. If you suck, be grateful FB is telling you before the market tells you. So now you have time to act on it
Thereâ€™s usually a big foundational problem but is easy to solve:

Sell better products
Ship faster
Improve Customer Support

[2.08.24, 4:53:23] ~â€¯Kim Romanov: Hi there! A question on US LLC taxes.
I live in Canada and have a corporation here for my store. But because of the high fees when receiving payments from the US market (3.5% internation fee + 30c + 1.5% currency conversion fee even when receiving payment in USD and payment to Wise in USD), i.e. a total of about 5.1% on each transaction, I decided to open an LLC in New Mexico, as recommended in the E-Commerce Tax Course, so that the Canadian corporation would be the managing corporation and the US LLC would be the operating one. An ESS participant shared with me that there can be double taxation of income in Canada when owning a US LLC, he said he had to close his US LLC because of this.

Is there anyone here with a similar bundle who lives in Canada. Or what is the tax situation when receiving payments on a US LLC in your country?

Source:
https://polaristax.com/us-llcs-cause-canadian-tax-problems/
&
https://faberllp.ca/us-llcs-cause-canadian-tax-problems/

[14.08.24, 16:35:01] Radek: Testing the offer had the biggest outcomes for us. You can play with price, testing different offers b2g1, various quantity discounts  etc. Also increasing the value - free shipping, extended guarantee, free gifts, ebooks, courses are the biggest levers. Check the biggest DTC brands and get inspiration from their funnel.

[28.08.24, 19:33:01] â€ª+47Â 973Â 16Â 810â€¬: Guys, how do you speed up your shopify store load speeds, when using heavy scripts, apps, and gempages to build your entire store? 

Our score is 26/100 when using page load speed websites.

Any input heavily appreciated!
[28.08.24, 20:22:00] ~â€¯Jacob: Here are over 50 actionable steps you can take to significantly speed up your Shopify store, especially when dealing with heavy scripts, apps, and custom page builders like Gempages:

1. **Optimize Images**: Compress images using tools like TinyIMG or JPEGmini without sacrificing quality. Use WebP format where possible.

2. **Lazy Load Images**: Implement lazy loading so images load only when they're in the viewport.

3. **Use a Content Delivery Network (CDN)**: Utilize a CDN to serve assets from the server closest to the user, reducing load times.

4. **Minify CSS, JavaScript, and HTML**: Minimize the size of these files by removing unnecessary characters, comments, and spaces.

5. **Reduce HTTP Requests**: Combine multiple CSS and JavaScript files into a single file to decrease the number of requests made by the browser.

6. **Remove Unused CSS and JavaScript**: Delete or comment out any code that is not being used on your site.

7. **Use Critical CSS**: Load only the CSS required for the visible part of the page, deferring other styles until needed.

8. **Limit Third-Party Apps**: Uninstall any unnecessary apps, and make sure to clean up any leftover code after uninstalling.

9. **Optimize Shopify Apps**: Restrict app features to the necessary pages and remove redundant app code.

10. **Reduce the Use of Sliders**: Replace sliders with a single, high-quality hero image to decrease load time.

11. **Replace GIFs with Static Images**: GIFs can be heavy, so opt for static images or CSS animations where possible.

12. **Preload Important Fonts**: Preload the most important fonts to ensure they are available immediately on page load.

13. **Use System Fonts**: Stick to system fonts to avoid the delay caused by loading custom fonts.

14. **Implement Browser Caching**: Enable browser caching to store assets locally on the userâ€™s device.

15. **Minimize Redirects and Fix Broken Links**: Reduce the number of redirects and ensure all links on your site are functional.

16. **Upgrade Your Theme**: Use a theme optimized for performance, with minimal CSS and JavaScript.

17. **Use Google Tag Manager**: Condense tracking codes into a single tag manager to reduce the number of requests.

18. **Optimize Mobile Performance**: Ensure your site is fully responsive and optimized for mobile users.

19. **Avoid Embedded Videos**: Use video embeds instead of directly uploading videos to your site to reduce load times.

20. **Enable AMP (Accelerated Mobile Pages)**: Implement AMP for faster loading on mobile devices.

21. **Optimize Liquid Code**: Clean up and streamline Liquid code in your theme to avoid unnecessary slowdowns.

22. **Remove Unused Shopify Apps**: Regularly audit and remove any apps that are not actively contributing to your storeâ€™s functionality.

23. **Use AJAX for Quick View**: Implement AJAX to load only the necessary product details when a user clicks a quick view, rather than preloading everything.

24. **Disable or Limit Pop-ups**: Reduce the use of pop-ups as they can add to load times.

25. **Preload Key Resources**: Preload the most crucial resources to speed up the rendering process.

26. **Enable Gzip Compression**: Compress files with Gzip to reduce the size of files sent to users.

27. **Reduce Image Dimensions**: Only upload images in the dimensions required for display.

28. **Limit Number of Fonts**: Use a minimal number of font variations and weights to reduce load times.

29. **Server-Side Rendering**: Use server-side rendering (SSR) judiciously, especially for pages that require dynamic content.

30. **Optimize Video Files**: Compress and optimize any videos before embedding them on your site.

31. **Reduce Cookie Size**: Limit the size and number of cookies your site uses, as these can affect performance.

32. **Use Efficient Image Formats**: Convert images to efficient formats like WebP for faster load times.

33. **Audit and Remove Excess Plugins**: Regularly audit installed plugins and remove or replace any that slow down your site.

34. **Optimize CSS Delivery**: Inline critical CSS and load other styles asynchronously.

35. **Defer Non-Critical JavaScript**: Defer loading of JavaScript that isnâ€™t essential for the initial render.

36. **Limit DOM Size**: Keep the number of DOM elements manageable to prevent excessive processing times.

37. **Avoid Third-Party Widgets**: Limit the use of third-party widgets like social media feeds that can slow down your site.

38. **Prioritize Visible Content**: Ensure that the content above the fold is prioritized and loads first.

39. **Use a Fast Hosting Provider**: If possible, choose a hosting provider that offers fast server response times.

40. **Reduce Image Count on Pages**: Limit the number of images on each page to reduce the overall load time.

41. **Enable HTTP/2**: HTTP/2 allows for multiple files to be loaded simultaneously, reducing load times.

42. **Use SVGs for Icons**: Replace icon images with scalable vector graphics (SVGs) for faster loading and scalability.

43. **Reduce the Size of Hero Images**: Optimize the size of hero images or use compressed formats.

44. **Implement Image Sprites**: Combine multiple images into a single sprite to reduce HTTP requests.

45. **Enable Deferred Loading**: Implement deferred loading for scripts and styles that are not needed immediately.

46. **Use Inline SVGs for Critical Icons**: Inline SVGs for crucial icons to reduce the number of requests made by the browser.

47. **Compress Scripts**: Use tools like UglifyJS to compress and optimize JavaScript files.

48. **Monitor Site Performance Regularly**: Use tools like Google PageSpeed Insights to continuously monitor and improve your siteâ€™s speed.

49. **Reduce the Number of Plugins**: Only use necessary plugins to minimize the performance impact on your site.

50. **Eliminate Render-Blocking Resources**: Ensure that no resources block the first paint of your site by deferring them or loading them asynchronously.

By implementing these techniques, you should see a significant improvement in your Shopify storeâ€™s load times, enhancing both user experience and conversion rates. Remember that optimizing site speed is an ongoing process, so regular monitoring and updates are essentialã€11â€ sourceã€‘ã€12â€ sourceã€‘ã€13â€ sourceã€‘ã€14â€ sourceã€‘ã€15â€ sourceã€‘.
[28.08.24, 20:55:46] MatÃ¡n Intsuper: There are many people in Fiverr with lots of reviews that can speed up your Shopify store itâ€™s very cheap and it works. You only pay if youâ€™re satisfied. I used it and it worked. â€<This message was edited>

[1.09.24, 3:06:11] ~â€¯Bony Ghadiya: Hey man! If I understand your question correctly, the data you feed to your account is correct. You can feed your account with data from Google Analytics, Google Tag Manager, simprosys or even custom coding  etc

The data on your Triple Whale dashboard does not report back to Google! But some tracking softwares offer that feature too, like Hyros

Variations of shopping: I assume you are asking for other shopping placements or how to expand the shopping platform! A Short answer would be YouTube (yes you can run shopping ads on YT) and use Pmax to use shopping for retargeting and remarketing to utilize your feed even more.

"How to refresh Google shopping data without affecting the original data?"

A simple solution is to duplicate your product on Shopify, which means you have more than one listing of the same product on GMC. Now, you can use new/duplicated products for your testing purposes. This way, your original feed/product does not get affected, but you can still test new shopping variables like images/titles/ pricing/ offers/ promotions.

Let me know if any questions

[12.09.24, 20:23:08] ~â€¯Mikael: Hey guys. You who use airwallex for payments. Does it work in EU for customers to purchase with their cards?

[12.09.24, 20:26:18] Carlos Leeseman: @â¨~Mike Ramseyâ©
[12.09.24, 20:42:17] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: EU entity/business <> EU consumer transaction = higher success rate.  UK entity (or any country outside of EU) <> EU consumer transaction, success rates will be lower.  Depends on issuing bank (customer bank) and how they play with Airwallex.  This really goes for any processor.  

Cross border processing will always have lower success rates unless you transact through a merchant of record or set-up entity where client is located and route your processing through that entity.
[12.09.24, 20:46:07] â€ª+47Â 973Â 16Â 810â€¬: Guys, any good, reliable resources on native ads? Who should I be learning from? Never done it before so I am 100% new to them, thank you! â€<This message was edited>
[12.09.24, 21:25:57] ~â€¯Mikael: Hmm.. do you experience big difficulties with taking payments to HK entidy from EU? Or is it just so small that its barely noticable?
[12.09.24, 22:26:03] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: What do you mean â€˜big difficulty?â€™  

If you are asking if you will have more failed transactions vs. processing EU entity <> EU consumer, then yes it will be more difficult to have higher CVR because your customers will try to check out and then the transaction will fail at a higher rate since you are routing through an HK entity vs. an EU entity for that EU consumer.  Again depends on issuing bank of consumer in EU and payment method selected!

This also depends on the product you are selling, AOV, demographic you are targeting, etc.  

Wallet payments such as PayPal have better authorization rates since it is a closed-loop payment system.  This is more card specific.  But you will pay more in fees for processing + currency fees flipping HKD to Euro for example.

Hope that makes sense.
[12.09.24, 22:26:46] ~â€¯Mukhtar: Hey guys, weâ€™ve been seeing a lot of incorrect customer addresses on Funnelish over the past few months.

They have most likely requested:

- â list of orders with tracking numbers

[13.09.24, 19:55:06] ~â€¯Jason Kwan: â€~â€¯Jason Kwan joined using a group link.
[13.09.24, 20:56:07] ~â€¯Jacob: â€This message was deleted.
[13.09.24, 20:57:07] ~â€¯Jacob: ğŸ“ˆ Gradually Increase Volume:
Start with small transactions ($100-500/day) and slowly increase by 10-20% per week. Avoid any sudden spikes that could trigger fraud alerts.

ğŸ’³ Diversify Payment Sources:
Make sure different customers are making purchases. Donâ€™t just use your own credit cardsâ€”it looks suspicious to Stripe. Spread out payments over time to keep things looking natural.

âš ï¸ Keep Chargebacks Low:
Try to keep chargebacks under 1%. Respond to any disputes quickly and offer great customer service to avoid complaints.

ğŸŒ Optimize Your Website:
Make sure your site follows Stripeâ€™s guidelines. Have clear product descriptions, refund policies, and contact details. Use 3D Secure to reduce fraud.

ğŸ¤ Be Transparent with Stripe:
If Stripe asks for any documents, send them ASAP. Also, if you have any spikes in volume, be proactive and explain why.

[19.09.24, 20:41:50] Alex  Fedotoff: All depends on their experience and results they deliver. Even $10k is fair if they make your life easier and help you produce 20X+ the profit. Good talent usually isnâ€™t very cheap unless you get them early when they are just starting out or just get lucky. 
One way to look at it: Lets say you make $100k a month in profit managing ads by yourself. Thatâ€™s a baseline. Then you bring in media buyer that helps getting the biz to $200k a month profit. So you just made more money and saved yourself some time to focus on bigger things in business. In that case, that person is def worth paying well to

One of our members here made $1 mil profit last month, his media buyer made $20K+ (with bonus structure put in place) while managing all the ads for many countries heâ€™s selling products in. Was $20k too much to pay for this? [24.09.24, 3:02:13] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: As an FYI - Wise is not a bank, but an MSB that has an e-money license.   You can hold funds there and these remain segregated if the company were to suffer major losses and they are stored in accounts through banks with FDIC insurance.  They do have protections in place,  but if I were to store cash Iâ€™d want it elsewhere and only use Wise as a way to move money and convert currency.  

Relay and Mercury are considered online banks and provide FDIC insurance via their banking partners.  A safer bet to keep larger sums of money sitting there in my opinion.

[24.09.24, 17:40:55] ~â€¯David B: Top tips. 

Ask for longer and shorter variations. 
Ask for more variations. 
Ask it to use a specific angle you know is working well for your ads. 
Ask it to focus on pain points.

Ask it to focus on benefits.

80% of the success of your copy will come from the hooks and headlines.

[2.10.24, 19:22:52] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: Hey All - on today's payments call, I wanted to address a lot of the common concerns I am seeing with many of you around reserves / holds as this is impacting seasoned sellers as well. 

Most of these issues are around reserve requirements and holds as you scale and also how these ratios are calculated. 

I will provide a specific breakdown on how payment processors calculate reserves and the rationales as to why they are doing this.  While Stripe is taking a much more aggressive approach as of late, these reserve calculations are relatively universal and can help you budget your cashflow heading into Q4.  Remember, always take a proactive approach to your business and get a back-up processor (or two) in place for the holiday season.  Relying on just 1 provider anymore is not a smart move so plan accordingly!

[11.10.24, 6:52:23] ~â€¯Tarlan: @â¨~Matteo Pellegriniâ© I have the same issue. 

I have automation for abandoned checkouts. It has 3 different flows and besides â€œproduct benefitsâ€ etc., in all of them I have a note saying â€œin case of payment failure, to call their bank to approve the purchase or to use an other cardâ€. 

Recently noticed more failed transactions and decided to add similar note near â€œcomplete purchaseâ€ button.

That small paragraph helped to recover more failed purchases than that 3 automated emails. 

You can A/B test and see if it will work for you too. 

Iâ€™ve been told from Funnelish Customer Service that, that kind of Paypal failure rate is normal.  Because most of the time customers just drop off on some step or change their mind. Probably best way would be to have â€œPaypal Express checkoutâ€ button coded in the checkout page.

[16.10.24, 22:47:44] ~â€¯Tarlan: For me good CTR is 40-50%. 

Sometimes same funnel with 40-50% CTR have 15-25% CTR in different market. 

Then I test different headlines, and picture. Until I hit at least 35% CTR.  

And I try to optimize all of my landing pages to max speed. 

I tested having Sticky CTA action button once I introduce the product in advertorial, vs on top of the page, and every time showing sticky CTA on top worked better for me in every market. 

Slightly lower CVR in the checkout but since more people going through the pages, funnel converts more.

[29.10.24, 9:05:13] ~â€¯Mikael: Hey fam. We launched 2 new brands with all new assets (except 1 brand that is using old pixel).

[29.10.24, 9:13:09] Jordi: @â¨Alex  Fedotoffâ© did hahaha
[29.10.24, 11:05:21] ~â€¯Santi Roa: How long did you had the old brand running?
[29.10.24, 11:05:30] ~â€¯Santi Roa: And when did you launch these 2 new brands?
[29.10.24, 11:09:10] ~â€¯Santi Roa: That's normal, I'd say.
Here are a few theories, and it depends on the question's answers:

1) Social proof. Your old brand probably looks more legit because it already has more online presence (i.e 20k social media followers vs 200)

2) Top of funnel.
People often see our ads between 3-7 times before buying. It varies depending on your brand but usually only 30% buys the first day they find your brand. Another 30% buys between 1 and 7 days, and the rest might take up to 6 months to buy
[29.10.24, 11:09:18] ~â€¯Santi Roa: You can survey that

[6.12.24, 0:17:13] ~â€¯Jacob: if you want to know how to find post id for flex ad - simple and easy method:

Go to Ads Manager: Open the Ads Manager and locate the campaign containing your Flex Ad.
Preview the Ad:
Click on the specific ad.
In the right-hand pane, click on "Preview".
View the Post ID:
In the Preview window, click "Facebook Post with Comments".
In the browser's address bar, look for the Post ID at the end of the URL. It typically looks like this:
bash
Copy code
https://www.facebook.com/{PageID}/posts/{PostID}
The number after /posts/ is your Post ID.

[20.12.24, 21:07:20] Carlos Leeseman: There are multiple options.

1. Work together with a fulfilment center who continues shipping when CNY, like Bestfulfill 
2. â Make visible on your website that due to busyness we delivery time is longer than normal with an expected delivery date. This will probably lower your conversion rate, but can still keep you selling at a profit
3. â Don't mention anything on your website, continue as you are doing now, and refund money when customers ask where their order is

[6.01.25, 15:34:05] ~â€¯Ğ˜ÑĞ»Ğ°Ğ¼: Hello Guys,

[6.01.25, 15:40:18] Jordi: Yeaa i have between 5 and 10% conversion rate because of them
[6.01.25, 15:42:13] ~â€¯Daniel Lai: yeah hiding the sales process increases conversions and aov a lot, so more profit therefore you can spend a lot more on ads and scale
[6.01.25, 15:45:13] ~â€¯L: How important is to make it look like an editorial page? 
Iâ€™m seeing a few brands running advertorials on Shopify on a regular page like it was a blog page of the brand
[6.01.25, 15:49:29] Jordi: I do that as well
[6.01.25, 15:51:08] ~â€¯David B: You have a bunch of options with advertorials. 

They can be branded or unbranded using a third party website.

1. Listicles - EG 7 reasons why. 
2. Reviews - (third-party) We tested the XYZ product and here's the truth. 
3. Review Comparison - (third-party) We tested the top 5 XYZ product and here's what we recommend. 
4. First-Person stories - I never thought I'd walk again until I discovered XYZ product.
5. News report - Scientific breakthrough shows that (Commonly believed problem) is NOT the real cause of (Customer pain point), here's what's really causing your (Customer pain point) 

You can have success with all different styles but they need to make sense with the rest of your funnel and they need to be specific to the customer's needs. 

They also need to be believable. 

If you tell someone in a wheel chair to take 1 pill a day and they'll be beating Usain Bolt in the 100m, they'll call BS.  

Hope that helps.
[6.01.25, 15:51:53] ~â€¯Ğ˜ÑĞ»Ğ°Ğ¼: Should it be on other domain name ? Which option is better?
[6.01.25, 15:52:23] Jordi: I dont but i havent tried any other option i was a bit lazy and did it the fast way
[6.01.25, 15:52:33] Jordi: I will test more advertorials in the near future
[6.01.25, 15:53:49] ~â€¯David B: I know a lot of brands that use third party domain names and then essentially run it like their own affiliate page for their products. It can make it look independent and more trustworthy especially if you can use a good authority figure for the third party site. EG a doctor, aesthetician, engineer. That sort of thing.
[6.01.25, 15:55:33] ~â€¯Ğ˜ÑĞ»Ğ°Ğ¼: Thanks for sharing

https://pages.thebarebeautybabes.com/is-hyaluronic-acid-a-potential-botox-alternative#intro â€<This message was edited>

You want to continue the customer journey. 

If I watch at anti-aging ad, then get sent to an anti-acne advertorial, I'm going to think I'm in the wrong place and leave. 

It should flow naturally and educate them on the thing that got them interested in the first place.
[6.01.25, 16:23:36] ~â€¯Ğ˜ÑĞ»Ğ°Ğ¼: Currently, I use only direct-selling creatives. It was mentioned earlier that we should hide the selling process. Does this mean I should avoid using creatives that directly sell?

Some products don't need a lot of explanation so you can keep things simple. 

In my experience, it's not so much hiding the sales process so much as delaying it so you can educate and handle objection before you present them with an offer.

[7.01.25, 9:14:04] Jordi: Any tips for abandoned checkouts? I created a very cute and funny email that get send but only recovered like 3 out of 50 checkouts... what is the normal KPI for that?
[7.01.25, 9:24:34] Topi: @â¨Jordiâ© this is our go to KPIs and flow, super simple
[7.01.25, 9:24:44] Topi: KPIS: 

1st email - +50% open / over 10% placed order rate

2nd email - +50% open / over 10% placed order 

3rd email - over 5% placed order 

4th email - over 5% placed order 

â€”

About emails: 

1st email - no discount, just reminder, keep super simple

2nd email - text based with discount (resend if no open) 

3rd email - urgency for the discount

4th email - text based,  increase discount + high urgency 

â€”

Tips: 

- Keep emails super simple and easy to digest

- Text based works super well

- Focus on A/B testing your headlines, you can clickbait more than on normal campaign emails

- Make sure possible discounts work, responsibility is on point, emails dont end up on spam or promotional
[7.01.25, 9:25:32] Topi: bonus: on 5th email you can write text based from founder, and ask reason why they did not purchase. People actually reply this email which helps trouble shooting and this email also gives around 3% placed order rate

[9.01.25, 10:21:06] ~â€¯seth: Metaâ€™s updated ad policies target websites and apps categorized under sensitive topics (health and wellness being the most prominent). These restrictions stem from a combination of legal and privacy concerns (and cases), aiming to eliminate the sharing of sensitive user data. Metaâ€™s is categorizing brands and their websites based on whether they associate user interactions with sensitive conditions, such as medical issues or provider-patient relationships. 

For advertisers in the US, EU and UK that are affected, this translates into reduced functionality of Metaâ€™s Business Tools, including blocked Events, meaning mid and lower funnel events (Add to Cart, Purchase) will be restricted. There will also be CAPI (Conversions API) Limitations and even server-side APIs will be unable to share or track restricted events.

These updates differentiate between partial and full restrictions. Hereâ€™s what that means:

Full Restrictions 

Complete blocking of all Meta tools for tracking or optimizing sensitive events. This includes Pixel, CAPI, and other Meta Business Tools.

No user data associated with restricted events will be processed or tracked.

Partial Restrictions 

Primarily affecting mid and lower funnel optimization.

Blocking of some pixel events.

No user data associated with restricted events will be processed or tracked.

â€[19.01.25, 13:08:47] ~â€¯Mo: â€image omitted
[19.01.25, 13:48:43] ~â€¯L: Guys do you issue seeing Facebook Feedback score?
[19.01.25, 14:12:59] ~â€¯Jacob: Unfortunately, the "Save my info" checkbox in Shop Pay is a feature managed by Shopify, and it is typically set to be pre-checked by default to streamline the checkout experience for returning customers. As a merchant, you do not have direct control over changing this default behavior in the checkout settings.

However, here are a few things you can do:

1. Contact Shopify Support

Shopify may be able to provide guidance or a custom solution, but in most cases, this behavior cannot be modified due to compliance and user experience considerations.


2. Customize Checkout (Shopify Plus Only)

If you're using Shopify Plus, you can customize your checkout process more extensively. This might allow you to modify or provide additional guidance about the checkbox. Consult your developer or Shopify's documentation for details.


3. Provide Transparency

Add a note in your privacy policy or on the checkout page explaining how Shop Pay works, so customers are aware of the feature and how their information is handled.


4. Customer Education

Include an FAQ or notice for customers about Shop Payâ€™s opt-out options. For example, they can uncheck the box before proceeding or remove their information later through the Shop app.


If you need help creating a customer-friendly explanation or adding notices to your store, let me know!

[21.01.25, 5:07:00] ~â€¯Luka: Just wanted to share a cool method that takes one-time effort to gets you free $$$ passively + email optins. I rarely see brands do this.

On your packaging or leaflet, add a warranty registration QR Code. Have it lead to an opt-in form and then redirect users to your catalog page upon submission. On the catalog page you can write a message confirming their warranty registration and give them a limited-time coupon code (or min spend threshold) to get them to shop again.

This also also a great way to obtain email optins from your Amazon/platform customers and train customers to shop on your website. We don't sell on Amazon so make sure to abide by their rules

[26.01.25, 17:29:10] ~â€¯Jacob: hey guys i wanted to give you tip i discover this week and it can save a lot of money for you: if you open your business manager, on a country that there is VAT there, facebook will charge you this IVA on top of the spend (for example, you spend 900$, they will charge you almost 170$ extra if the tax is 17%) - and you dont get any traffic with this tax to be clear. and they pretty hiding it, it's not so clear at all, you can see it if you will go to your billing and click on your transcation, than you will see what go to tax and what went for spend. and unfortuntately, there is no way to change the country once it was opened (i talk with customer service on phone, it's impossible at moment)

what you can do? open another "portfolio" , on my business manager, i can open until 5 portoflios, which every portofolio include 5-10 ad accounts, and than you put it on a country that doesent pay VAT (like hong kong for example or whatever, its doesent really matter) - and than you will avoid this bullshit

[31.01.25, 12:14:45] ~â€¯Adam K.: I have been doing aff seo for 8 yrs, with quite decent results and I can not recommend any agency because mostly you will be charged for organic results + they will spend around 1h of work per month on your project.

First you need to know whats your goal:
a) new traffic from general keywords in your niche and position your product there
b) make your site at the top for your particular product unique name (not general keyword like lawn mower, because there you have no chance for general terms without knowledge in seo )

if b) - it would be pretty easy for independent seo consultant
You should form a plan formed on topical map of terms you want to cover/build your blog/site about

To sum up - seo is very long term game where you invest without guarantee of success. Its content + links game. 

PM if you have any questions

[3.02.25, 23:27:24] ~â€¯Kevin Krieg: You can use chrome extension like Fireshot to screenshot/save the whole page as a pdf.

Its very handy when talking to devs. 

There is also a chrome extension called html to design. It grabs a page and you can upload it to figma, instantly making it editable.  Thats also very handy when talking to devs.

Or if its a simple page and not complicated, I would use chrome extension "singlefile" to download the pages html, css and script. Then upload it to chatgpt and say you want the same stuff coded. With a bit of communicating and tweaking it will make the same thing for you. Only effective for simple stuff, otherwise it takes too long. Dev better in that case

[5.02.25, 3:54:16] ~â€¯Dayu Yang: Hereâ€™s our initial announcement to ecommops clients (note especially #3) -

We sent out the following statement to all of our clients
*Important UPDATED Notice for fulfillment for 2/5*1. Due to changes to tariff rates and the elimination of the de minimus exemption, for orders to the USA starting today carriers will pre-collect 30% of the declared value to cover custom duties. Our current default declared value is at 5 USD per unit and 10 USD for more than 1 unit in an order. Some products (such as clothing and textiles) have higher tariffs so the difference will be debited or credited after customs applies the final calculated rates based on HTS codes. This will update and reflect in the Google Sheet â€˜Order Historyâ€™ tab.2. If you already have HTS codes and COGS values for your SKUs please share with us, otherwise we will apply default HTS codes and default COGS. Our default HTS classifications are based on product SKU category and type characteristics. COGS we will default declare at 5 USD for single unit orders and 10 USD for multiunit orders.Â 3. Each order will be subject to an additional carrier processing charge of 2.74 USD (20 RMB) per order. Â Our advice is to pause US fulfillment on Wed 05th Feb as fees and transit times may change.We understand some orders can't wait any longer and they have to be sent out. Please confirm to us that you agree with the above new fees. Without clear approval we will hold China fulfillment to the USA.

[7.02.25, 9:35:31] ~â€¯Bestfulfillâ€”william: Updates on USA tariffs!!!

the $3 each parcel cost customs clearance fee is fixed if Using T11 way of customs clerance,

important more and more company like yunepxress and yanwen are charging less like $1.5 per order extra because they use traditional B2b business custom clearance ways, bulk sending the parcels prepacked and then change usps labels from USA warehouse. 

the transtional 1-2 weeks from the USA tariffs will be tough, so our suggestion is get the orders shipped no matter how. 

 we have 4 possible ways to solve this, 

1: prepack ourselves and ship by dhl or fedex way. and then transfer it to usps from our USA warehouse
2: use lines like yunexpress or yanwen, which is roughly $2 higher with taxes included 
3: air cargo shipping to USA warehouse and ship from there. (light items)
4: container shipping to USA warehouse and ship from there. (heavy stuff)
[7.02.25, 9:51:48] ~â€¯Dayu Yang: to clarify, yunexpress is charging 20 rmb (~$2.75 USD) per order, as is 4px. Yanwen is the one charging less, as low as 10rmb ($1.37 USD). 

All of these three couriers are using t11 informal clearance. Main difference is that Yanwen is attempting to combine parcels together and declare as one, which personally I think is risky.

These costs are all based on the formal minimum MPF https://www.help.cbp.gov/s/article/Article-1128?language=en_US

"MPF for informal entries has a set fee and can range from $2.62, $7.85 or $11.78 per shipment.â€ $2.62 is a bit less than $2.75 of course, but given exchange rate fluctuations its more or less just a buffer. 

In addition, I advise everyone be very careful to declare value too low. There is a lot of uncertainty if this is legitimate and there are already anecdotal news (but not substantiated) that US customs is already noticing a high volume of low value declarations. 

Our VIP rep at yunexpress is strongly cautioning us against doing this, and that they are urgently working on more clarification. 

Ongoing updates: 

https://docs.google.com/document/d/17B49xePSVdaPezKaAVbKmkl2eogEByuQZQODm9Q-h3I/edit?usp=sharing

Yes i do know many smaller couriers are offering lower fees / lower duty rates but I wouldnâ€™t trust their stability right now esp if you have backlogged CNY orders.

[8.02.25, 2:34:57] ~â€¯Dayu Yang: ğŸš¨ TRUMP DELAYS DE MINIMIS ORDER ğŸš¨

It's true everyone, 

Article from reuters: https://www.reuters.com/business/trump-signs-order-delaying-tariffs-de-minimis-imports-china-2025-02-07/ 

And most importantly, the official white house update:

https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/02/amendment-to-duties-addressing-the-synthetic-opioid-supply-chain-in-the-peoples-republic-of-china/ 

"  Section 1.  Amendment.  Regarding the Executive Order of February 1, 2025 (Imposing Duties to Address the Synthetic Opioid Supply Chain in the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China), the following shall replace subsection (g) of section 2:
     â€œ(g)  Duty-free de minimis treatment under 19 U.S.C. 1321 is available for otherwise eligible covered articles described in subsection (a) of this section, but shall cease to be available for such articles upon notification by the Secretary of Commerce to the President that adequate systems are in place to fully and expediently process and collect tariff revenue applicable pursuant to subsection (a) of this section for covered articles otherwise eligible for de minimis treatment.â€"

Basically legal speak for delaying the recent order for the elimination of the de minimis exemption for China. 

HOWEVER, still clearly leaving the option to implement it formally once systems are in place. 

For now we should be in the clear. But will need to update later once we fully confirm smooth customs processing later in the day. Given the backlog at customs we STILL expect a certain amount of delays regardless of this announcement.

And keep in mind that this does NOT mean the order is cancelled, only delayed. So we still strongly advise taking the appropriate actions to prepare. 

For the time being though, a big breath of relief for DTC parcel fulfillment from China. 

For those who have pre-paid customs fees for existing parcels wondering how you will get refunded back. For now the mechanism is not clear, but we will find out asap. 

Update more when we have more information.

[9.02.25, 1:48:27] ~â€¯Jacob: If you're constantly getting picked up by product-scouting apps (like Ecomhunt, Pexda, Minea, or other "winning product" finders), and it leads to fake DMCA takedowns from other dropshippers, you need to protect your store and product visibility strategically.

How to Avoid Detection by Winning Product Apps
These apps scan for trending products by scraping ad data, sales trends, and Shopify stores. Hereâ€™s how you can stay under the radar:

1. Mask Your Store from Scrapers
Block Common Scrapers & Spy Tools
Add bot-blocking code to your robots.txt file or use apps like:

Traffic Guard (Shopify app)
Shopify Protect
Blocky: Fraud Country Blocker
These prevent unwanted bots and competitors from analyzing your site.

Disable Shopify Theme Detection
Many tools identify winning stores through Shopify theme detectors. Use an app like Booster Theme Cloaker or modify your theme settings to remove theme-related footprints.

2. Launch in Stealth Mode
Use Password-Protected Pages for Testing
Before going live, test your ads with a hidden, password-protected page to see how they perform.

Run Ads in Less Scrutinized Regions First
Most "winning product" tools scan US, UK, and major European countries. Test your ads in Brazil, Mexico, UAE, or South Korea before scaling in high-competition markets.

Avoid Using Shopify Payments Directly
Many scrapers target Shopify Payment users. Using an external processor (Stripe, Payoneer, or a private gateway) can make it harder for these apps to detect your store.

3. Prevent Competitors from Reverse-Engineering Your Ads
Use Cloaking for Facebook & Google Ads
If youâ€™re running paid ads, competitors can easily copy your campaigns. Tools like TrafficArmor or RedTrack can help cloak your landing pages, making it harder for ad spies to track you.

Change Product Names & Descriptions
Scrapers look for common product titles and descriptions. Modify yours to unique, creative names that aren't easy to search.

Pixel Splitting for Retargeting
Instead of retargeting with a Facebook pixel alone, use server-side tracking to prevent Facebook Ad Library from exposing your campaign.

4. Prevent False DMCA Attacks
File a Counter-DMCA Immediately
If you receive a false DMCA from another dropshipper:

Respond with a Counter-Notice via Shopify (if they host your store).
Request Proof of Ownership â€“ Most dropshippers wonâ€™t have actual trademarks or patents.
Trademark Your Own Branding â€“ Even a simple logo and brand name trademark can help you fight back.
Use a Different Supplier or Private Label
If the same product is being resold by multiple dropshippers, consider contacting the manufacturer to get a unique version with your logo or packaging.

Diversify Sales Channels
If Shopify becomes a problem, try selling through:

Woocommerce (WordPress)
ClickFunnels (for single-product stores)
A separate marketplace (like Amazon or Etsy, depending on the product)
Final Thoughts
The best way to prevent getting picked up is to be LESS OBVIOUS in the first few days.**
Don't launch in major markets immediately â€“ test in lower-competition regions.
Consider switching to a different store platform if Shopify visibility becomes a constant issue.
Fight false DMCAs by gathering supplier proof and registering your branding.

We ALWAYS write all of our copy in English. This is easier, faster, cheaper, etc. As soon as our copy is finished, we translate it with ChatGPT to formal German/Dutch at 5th grade level, which makes sure that 90% of it is already good. [21.02.25, 16:42:08] ~â€¯CocowğŸ˜ˆ: If I may , there is a lot of time confusion between TW and wetracked. 

Triple whale = attribution tool which means it tells you the road and other stuff based on their algorithm and attribution ways. You can see your sells for every touch point where a client comes from and get an idea of how the revenue come from. You can have an AI attribution splitting (with post purchase survey) , last click, first click, splitted by every touch point and so on. This can help you as you could see blended roas for every channel and avoid the countless overlapping of every channel because everyone one to get the attribution. 

Example: a client click on meta ad, goes on google via shopping , and then buy via Klaviyo. Everyone will take the credit and TW tells you what drove mostly the sale, you can as well split the revenue of the sell by 3 , and other attribution systems. 

Everything is mostly triggered bi UTMs via social media plateforms and emails and then for organic search it detects. A client is identified by multiple parameters so that TW can track their journey. 

TW can help you as well to calculate your profit , have kpis, dashboards and so on 


For we tracked( or Bily, or Elevar for example) , this is a CAPI. 

The only job they do is by server , they provide the events back to your Meta, Google ADS, and other plateforms to feed the algorithm
 
In my opinion you should run with both. One to feed the plateforms, and other one to have better visibility on your blended roas. Some brands actually manage the ads with TW because it avoids the overlapping (at least better than meta and google campaign manager) 

Important: TW has developed in 2024 a CAPI AS WELL like we tracked, its name is sonar. I do not know if they connect with funnelish but this is certainly something you can ask them ! 

Hope this clarifies :))
[21.02.25, 16:43:57] ~â€¯Mikael: Perfect bro thx for the information. yes I decided to go with both For now. Just integrated Triple whale this morning and kept Wetracked for now to send the data back (even tho I saw that Triple whale have their own program called SONAR, that sends back data to Meta)

---

Job Title: Motion Graphics Animator for Medical & Product Visualization (X-Ray Style Effects)

Job Overview:

We are looking for a skilled motion graphics animator with experience in medical-style animations, product visualization, and augmented reality overlays. The project involves creating an X-ray-like effect that simulates blood circulation, nerve activity, or muscle stimulation over real footage of a wearable product.

If you have expertise in After Effects, Cinema 4D, Blender, or similar software and can create semi-transparent anatomical effects that enhance product demonstrations, weâ€™d love to work with you!


---

Responsibilities:

Create realistic X-ray-style animations that overlay on real human body footage.

Design animated veins, nerves, blood flow, or muscle stimulation effects.

Integrate motion-tracking techniques to ensure the animation follows the body's natural movement.

Use glow, transparency, and augmented reality-like effects to create a visually engaging demonstration.

Work with provided product videos and apply the necessary VFX enhancements.

Ensure a smooth blend between the real footage and animated effects.



---

Requirements:

Proficiency in After Effects, Cinema 4D, Blender, or other relevant motion graphics tools.

Experience in medical animations, anatomical visualization, or product marketing effects.

Strong understanding of motion tracking and overlay techniques.

Ability to create realistic, glowing, and semi-transparent animations.

A portfolio showcasing similar animation styles (X-ray effects, nerve/blood flow simulations, or body enhancement visuals).

Knowledge of compositing and VFX techniques to seamlessly integrate animations into footage.



---

Preferred Skills (Not Required, But a Plus):

Experience with 3D rendering for anatomical structures.

Familiarity with AI-based animation tools for enhancing realism.

Ability to collaborate with medical illustrators or product designers for accuracy.



---

How to Apply:

If you have experience in creating X-ray-style product animations or medical motion graphics overlays, please send us:
âœ… Your portfolio with similar animations
âœ… A brief description of your workflow and tools
âœ… Your pricing/rate and estimated delivery time

Looking forward to working with talented motion designers who can bring science and innovation to life through visuals!
