[16.03.25, 21:07:55] ~â€¯Wouter Akika: Dear Aimerce Client,

TLDR; This is an FYI / No action required. Do not worry. Nothing is breaking.

This is Yiqi. I'm reaching out about the error message many of you are seeing on your Events Manager or Ads Manager dashboards. This started happening today. The error states that "Events from the Server are not Deduplicated.â€

Events Manager:

image (207) (1).png
Ads Manager:

Screenshot 2025-03-16 at 09.01.31 (1).png


Whoâ€™s affected?
Brands that are using Shopify Native CAPI.
Brands that were using Shopify Native CAPI and recently switched to Aimerce within the last 30 days.
Whoâ€™s NOT affected?
Brands that are on Aimerce for more than 30 days.
What happened and should I be worried?
No. For now, from what I know, this is happening across the board on all brands that were/are sending events from both Conversions API and the browser Pixel in the last 30 days. I DO NOT believe you actually have duplicate events.

One of the easiest ways to verify is to do a quick event counting for Purchase events. Select the last 7 days (or yesterday), check the Purchase event number. Go to your Shopify dashboard, count the last 7 days (or yesterday) order number, to see if they match.

p.s. Sometimes there will be plus or minus 5 orders depending on the timezone but it should be very close.

image - 2025-03-16T132140.614 (1).png
Understanding how deduplication works
Facebook uses event_id parameter as an identifier that can uniquely distinguish between similar events. Facebook will only need to deduplicate if events are sent from both the Conversions API and the browser Pixel.

Aimerce handles events differently, in a better and cleaner way. Aimerce deduplicates both browser and server events and only sends from the server side. That's why you wouldn't see this error if you are on Aimerce alone in the past 30 days.

Why am I seeing it if I have been on Aimerce for more than 30 days?
If this is the case, you should look into whether you have anything else besides Aimerce connecting with your pixel:

Do you have a GTM tag on the site?
Do you have Facebook Data Sharing turned on?
Do you have another third-party app?
If you see one single green line from Server in Purchase event, you are all good: this is from Aimerce deduplicated events.

If you are seeing a blue line from Browser, you should look into my questions above.

image - 2025-03-16T133448.704.png


Yiqi (yee-chee) Wu
Founder & CEO @ Aimerce
Mobile: +1-650-644-9060
Book a demo with me

[19.03.25, 18:50:19] ~â€¯Sonu Duhra: Leverage RDR/CDRN. How does this works?
[19.03.25, 19:17:58] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: RDR and CDRN are chargeback prevention alert tools that you can install that will allow you to refund a customer or resolve amicably, prior to it going to full blown chargeback status on your processing.

The alerts serve as a feature that triggers a notification to you and you can refund the customer without the CB hitting your processing account.  There are providers in here such as Chargeblast who can set you up with these tools.  Highly recommended to keep your processing account clean as you scale to avoid funding holds or entire account shutdowns with processors.

@â¨~Qi (Chargeblast)â©

[19.03.25, 19:42:23] ~â€¯Qi (Chargeblast): Here are a couple of slides I presented at the Merchant Risk Council (MRC) conference in Vegas last week
[19.03.25, 19:43:17] ~â€¯ğŸ¥‡: does high Refund rate affect account ?
[19.03.25, 19:43:23] ~â€¯Qi (Chargeblast): Yes
[19.03.25, 19:43:31] ~â€¯Qi (Chargeblast): Want to keep it below 15%
[19.03.25, 19:43:38] ~â€¯Qi (Chargeblast): 10 - 15%
[19.03.25, 19:44:16] ~â€¯ğŸ¥‡: So between 10-15% is not considered high risk
[19.03.25, 19:45:00] ~â€¯Qi (Chargeblast): Itâ€™s definitely not good to be there, but thereâ€™s nuances like industry. For example, clothing has refund rate of 25% because of so many returns.
[19.03.25, 19:45:11] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: High refund rate typically means merchandise is bad OR you have high pressure upsells.  Higher the refund rate means you are likely engaging in opt ins without user realizing or high pressure funnel.  And this does impact your account reviews, holds, etc.  So keep an eye on it.
[19.03.25, 19:45:19] ~â€¯Qi (Chargeblast): I would say keep it below 10% and it doesnâ€™t get flagged. Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve seen.
[19.03.25, 19:48:47] ~â€¯ğŸ¥‡: and you mean overall rate or just last 30days ?
[19.03.25, 19:51:03] ~â€¯Sonu Duhra: so basically tracking number is worthless? So they need prove of delivery like a signature or photo? Should I not fight disputes with Klarna in the future or is it more of a delay issue?
[19.03.25, 19:51:31] ~â€¯Qi (Chargeblast): Most acquirers look at metrics based on last 3 months
[19.03.25, 19:54:34] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: Greatly depends on your products, region you are selling to, your demographic, length of time in business, etc.

Some regions of the world have higher return rates than others and if you are selling clothing, then that industry as a whole just has a higher rate of return.

For example, I have a client selling hearing aids to the US with a return rate of 20%, but that is considered average for that vertical vs. other verticals.  Plus he is dealing with older clientele who are a pickier on a medical related item.

If you were to ballpark it, 10% refund rate or below is tolerable, but if you are just warming up your account and you have a high refund rate that typically indicates a problem and you have to adjust accordingly.  So processors will be less tolerable with high refund rates out the gate.

CB rates should always be <1% to avoid processor issues.  Lower the better.

Hope that helps
â€[19.03.25, 19:58:37] ~â€¯Mo: â€image omitted
[19.03.25, 20:08:19] ~â€¯Avv. Isidoro Capuano: Itâ€™s not worthless, but each payment processor or platform has its own Terms and Policies that all merchants shall consider in order to avoid unpleasant consequences such as â€œKlarna refunding orders even tho I shipped the itemâ€. 2020-2025 is quite a tricky period in which platforms are under pressure and they usually side with consumers (example: Stripe refunding within 5 days under section 5.6 of the terms claiming unauthorized charges or Klarna refunding under their own Shipping Policy that beware, changes in accordance with your region at the moment of signing up). The recommendation is to always download the proper and applicable terms and abide by them. Example: https://x.klarnacdn.net/cdn-klarna-com/1.0/shared/content/policy/shipping/en_us/MerchantProtectionTerms.pdf?utm_source=chatgpt.com this is Klarnaâ€™s Protection Program. Always make sure to get and secure all the evidence in order to challenge their actions (unwanted) within the timeframe given by the same terms. Example: You wonâ€™t be able to overturn a dispute even tho shipping the item if you havenâ€™t uploaded the tracking number within the timeframe given by Klarna. Then youâ€™ll have lost the dispute and the item unless you go after the consumer yourself privately to reclaim the payment that the payment processor has reversed.

[3.04.25, 3:41:35] ~â€¯Jacob: Hi, first of all, there is no "one" method, every expriencied media buyer eventually mix some methods with time because there is a lot of testing in it.

But anyhoo, something basic could be:

1.) First of all decide your budget because it's important and will determine what you will do.
2.) Let's take $500 for a day for this example.
3.) You can create 10 adsets, with 3 ads inside of them. 50$ each. or 5 of 100$, seriously there is no right or wrong. but don't put to little like 10$/20$ it will take to much time.
4.) Now for the strategy of the ads...
5.) You can really play with it - in the ESS course there is a good model by one of the agencies that make a table for video editors and it's shows the levels of the market by eughene schwartz.
6.) So what this model shows is basically the awareness levelsâ€”from completely unaware, to problem aware, solution aware, and product aware. And each of those stages needs a totally different ad vibe.
For example:
If you're targeting cold traffic (unaware), don't go pitching the product right away. Instead, focus on the pain point or tell a relatable story that hooks them emotionally.
If they're warm (solution aware), then it's all about why your product is the best choice, maybe with a cool demonstration or powerful social proof.
And if they already know your product? Then offer, urgency, scarcity. Straight up.
7.) The beauty of having multiple ad sets is that you can test all these angles at the same time. Maybe one ad set is cold traffic with emotional storytelling, another one is more logical and benefit-focused, and another one is just straight up "hereâ€™s why this offer is insaneâ€”go grab it now."
8.) anyhoo - it's not a most, but it one framework. if you put my message in gpt and ask for more, youll get more frameworks for this 10 adsets.
9.) track performance - the fact you put 50$ does not mean you need to let it all spend, track the numbers, checkout cost, clicks, conversion rate, but if you just warming, i will sometimes even keep losing ad for few days just to warm the pixel
10.) after you have some winners - you can put them inside cbo - with 3/5 duplicated adsets (again this is one CBO method of duplication, there are others... - for example you can put the winners, and make 5 adsets inside the cbo with five different lookalikes and see what performing the best - each adset - different lookalike)
12.) cbo start with 50$/100$ minimum - and if its profitable you can up the budget by 25% each day and duplicate it by 2/3 times each day and see how it performs

again this is just one strategy and you can change things inside â€<This message was edited>
â€[3.04.25, 4:21:05] ~â€¯Bestfulfillâ€”william: â€image omitted

* Current tariff rates impacting suppliers

[9.04.25, 20:00:58] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: Hey Guys. Apologies for the long message and being a bit MIA in the group. The tariff stuff has been keeping us busy. Here are 10 things weâ€™ve been thinking about and sharing with our clients and we wanted to share it here too in case itâ€™s helpful.

1. No One Knows the "Final" Tariff Details Yet
Thereâ€™s still no clarity onÂ how high the new tariffs will beÂ â€” they could beÂ 104%, 129% (still unknown if section 301 is still in place as an FYI), or something else entirelyÂ â€” orÂ how broadly theyâ€™ll be appliedÂ (just China, or China plus other parts of Asia?). We also donâ€™t know which product categories will be affected or how implementation will roll out. We anticipate uncertainty to continue for the near-future.

2. While Tariff Numbers Are Unclear, Plan for De Minimis to Be Removed
Tariffs may still be TBD, butÂ de minimis removal is looking very likely.Â This means all shipments into the U.S. under $800 could now be taxed â€” a big hit to brands relying on direct-from-China fulfillment.Â And itâ€™s not just about cost:Â longer delivery times from ChinaÂ could lead to moreÂ refund requests, lower customer satisfaction, and fewer repeat purchasesÂ â€” all of which hurt your LTV and CAC efficiency.

3. Work Directly With Factories â€” Not Just Fulfillment Companies
Fulfillment partners help with logistics, but not your product costs.Â Good quality factories are very collaborative and will help you come up with ways to reduce your costs by purchasing certain raw materials or buying at certain volumes to help bring down your cost.Â From our experience, fulfillment and trade companies typically mark up prices by 30%-100+%

4. Consider Hybrid Fulfillment or Fulfillment from the U.S.
Consider taking a hybrid fulfillment model (fulfill from US and China-based warehouse based on location of the customer) or consider fulfilling directly from the US (bulk ship to US 3PL). Yes, tariffs still apply when importing in bulk â€” but there are ways to consolidate shipment to lower tariff/duty payment. There are 2 benefits - lower per unit fulfillment cost and faster delivery to the customer - which means fewer refund requests, which prevents your CAC from creeping up.Â 

5. Diversify Market (look beyond US)
Scaling intoÂ international marketsÂ (like the EU, UK, or Canada) can help offset U.S. margin compression. If youâ€™re currently U.S.-only, youâ€™re more exposed to changes in domestic logistics and trade policy.

6. Diversity Manufacturing (Where Numbers work out)
Diversifying doesnâ€™t mean ditching China â€” it means adding a second factory base (like theÂ U.S., Mexico, or Europe) for flexibility and regional fulfillment. This doesnâ€™t apply for every industry, but for some industries like skincare and supplements, this is very doable. This can significantly bring down your cost due to the tariffs. That said, this is NOT a guarantee b/c of the changing policies. Manufacturing costs in the US are increasing due to greater demand and their reliance on China for ingredients and machines.Â 
-If you're targeting Europe, Australia, etc. youâ€™ll need to still produce in China since the numbers make sense.Â 
-Anyone thats selling gadgets will still need to produce in China since the US is not set up properly, nor is it even cost effective to produce gadgets. If you sell apparel, you can explore working with other countries since theyâ€™re more competitive than China on price.Â 
(Weâ€™ve been working with a lot of skincare and supplements brands to set up U.S. production and making sure it makes sense economicallyâ€” you'll need to carefully compare total landed cost, not just per-unit price.)

7. Thereâ€™s No One-Size-Fits-All Strategy â€” You Need to carefully compare numbers
Every brand is different. What works for a $60 skincare serum wonâ€™t work for a $20 phone charger. A lot of what we've been doing with brands is to help them figure out steps 4-6 (fulfillment strategy, target market and manufacturing strategy) to optimize for cost and on-time fulfillment.Â  Make decisions based on your numbers â€” not someone elseâ€™s playbook.Â 

8. Review and Optimize Your HTS Codes to reduce cost
While the tariffs are applied across all product categories, they are not the same when it comes to duties. Sometimes an HTS code for a product falls under two HTS codes. One could be a common HTS code used for the exact product, but another could be used due to the products function. In some cases, like weâ€™ve seen in the past, the difference in duties can be in range of 6%. If youâ€™re importing large volumes of product into the US, the duties savings can be significant.Â 

9. Negotiate Better Payment Terms With Manufacturers
For those that have an established relationship with their manufacturer, try working on paying a 20% deposit for your order. Then paying 50% upon completion of production and paying the final 30% 30 days after delivery. If youâ€™re placing orders valued at $300k, for instance, thatâ€™s $90k of money freed up for a month that you can put into marketing and scaling up your business.Â 

10. Smaller Dropshipping Brands Are Most at Risk; opportunity for medium-large brands.
Smaller businesses, especially pure dropshipping businesses (that are not focused on building a brand and scaling) are most likely going to die out with the de minimus removal. They'll have to pivot to selling in other markets, such as the EU, UK, Canada and Austrailia. This is a tough period for everyone, but could allow 8-9 figure brands to gain more market share in the US in the long term. This of course hinges on them having good control over cashflow and production cost.Â 

Hope this is helpful and stay strong everyone. Hit me up if I can be helpful with anything. Iâ€™m also going to be doing a live call with @â¨Alex  Fedotoffâ© tomorrow to talk about this stuff.

[15.04.25, 20:39:51] Carlos Leeseman: Hey guys, we have little problem on META.

We are infected like all others with Facebook health restrictions and our domain is blocked, preventing us from using any event. Our current CAPI solutions still works, as they use their own domain for the events attribution, but this is actually not allowed and is also bad for the algorithm of the ads, which can decreases performance.

So 9/10 CAPI solutions, like Aimerce, etc are not usable for us because the attribution is through own domain, which blocked. 

Does anyone have any suggestions on what we can best do? Creating new store is not an option and continuing to use our current CAPI solutions is possible, but very risky.

For example, is it possible to connect a second domain to Shopify, for Facebook only, without having to change the main/primary domain name?
[15.04.25, 21:24:53] Radek: Not sure if this is the answer youâ€™re looking for, but restrictions are applied on the domain level, so basically the only thing you need to do is to send traffic to the domain which is not categorised as health and wellness. What we did:
1. Use new domain variation e.g. trybrand, getbrand, etc
2. â Duplicate your funnel and get rid of any medical conditions, including in the reviews
3. â Relaunch your ads to the new domain

You can use old pixel, you can use winning ads including medical condition. The most important is that website part must be compliant.

You will lose engagement on your ads but can rebuild it on the compliant funnel.

Weâ€™re not using shopify, but I am quite sure you can connect multiple domains to the store.

Hope it helps
[15.04.25, 23:27:59] Carlos Leeseman: Okay yeah this is easy for funnels, but not if youâ€™re a brand and using Shopify.

[15.04.25, 23:58:42] ~â€¯Jeremy: I'm working with a client that's affected by this too. We've managed to navigate this by using Triple Whale's Sonar and sending the custom event New Customer Purchase to Meta. This event isn't blocked by Meta and is triggered by any new customer purchase. We're now optimizing all sales campaigns for the conversion event New Customer Purchase. This set up works well and has allowed us to maintain the normal ad performance. Let me know if you have any questions about this.

[24.04.25, 3:12:42] ~â€¯Bestfulfillâ€”william: Tariffs updates!!!

If u are too worried about the tariff cost too much turbulence in your businesses, u need calm down and look at how history goes back to 1929. Will trump let it happen again ? Of course not, he is giving himself an out every few days, and saying he wants get the deal down within 30 days, Again, he is a business man, he probably know more about history than any presidents in the history of the US.

A little story about myself, back to year 2014, I was a sales man in a watch resell company selling on aliexpress, the store I manage have only 3-4 orders a day, and everyday I send a message to those new buyers and asking them feedback about the pocket watches they bought from us at $3 with shipping, a lot of them turned to be my life changing people like Robert nava, who is the first batch of coaches, many of u guys probably know him or learned from him.  So whats my point here? Treat your clients like friends, talk with them, they will stay with u no matter how,  several month later, the stores I manage reach 100 orders easily and within 1 year the I sell most of the pocket watch in the market, and all the pocket watches factories know my name even I never met them before, I am getting a lot of bulk orders even for thousands of dollars, remember its a 2-3$ pocket watch with free shipping, not only they buy pocket watches from me, they buy many other watches from me, wooden watches, mechanical watches, then I find out the truth of selling, talk with your clients and treat them well, thats how Bestfulfill started with no advertising but solving problems for clients and then words of mouth, last year 2024 we did 400m revenue.

Although my business is a little bit different from e-commerce brands but the logic is same, so if u are paying more to get a loyal customer with higher cost, are u willing to do that?

[25.04.25, 8:24:04] ~â€¯Dayu Yang: Hereâ€™s an announcement and comparison prices on base rates weâ€™re sending to our clients 
===
The logistics company has provided the latest DDP rates for the U.S. route. Since today's (April 25) order fulfillment will still be settled at the old rates, we will update your quotation sheet tomorrow (April 26).

To make price comparison easier for you, EcommOps will directly update the prices of existing routes instead of creating new ones. Meanwhile, we have provided the specific price increases for each weight in advance. See the data below for details.

Under the latest plan, both the Regular Line and Liquid Line now support DDP services, so electronics and cosmetics can still be shipped to the U.S.

However, it is currently uncertain whether the U.S. customs will experience significant delays or conduct stricter reviews on declared values after the new policy takes effect. Therefore, we recommend pausing U.S. order fulfillment starting from April 26 until May 6, after the May Day holiday. By then, we will offer further advice based on the latest situation.

We will proceed with the suspension by default. If you fully understand the associated risks and price adjustments and wish to continue shipping to the U.S., please notify us separately after this message.

[5.05.25, 1:19:14] ~â€¯David B: The UK is in a bit of a mess right now because of changes to the tax regulation. The average person has less spending power. In times like these, people tend to gravitate back towards "known brands" and "household names" even if they are more expensive because they feel less risky. This could explain some of the performance issue in the UK. I predict it will stabilise soon.
[5.05.25, 1:19:49] ~â€¯Brendan Oâ€™ Connell: Whatâ€™s happening with the tax regulation? Thanks for this David
[5.05.25, 1:20:35] ~â€¯Damjan Topalovic: appreciate it
[5.05.25, 1:21:36] ~â€¯David B: Small businesses are getting hammered at the moment because of changes to the taxable thresholds. So if you employ people, you tax bill is going up. What that means is that a lot of businesses have now raised their prices passing on that cost to the end consumer.
[5.05.25, 1:22:12] ~â€¯David B: The current Labour government is not very popular. They've made some very poor choices in my opinion.
[5.05.25, 1:24:35] ~â€¯Brendan Oâ€™ Connell: This explains a lot cheers buddy

[19.05.25, 11:32:09] ~â€¯David B: Let's talk about VSLs... 

Hey guys. I see a lot of talk about VSLs and whenever I ask what you're all needing help with, VSLs is always top of that list. 

After writing literally hundreds of them I can tell you now that MOST of the advice out there is complicated as sh*t. 

Writing VSLs is not hard when you know how and there are a few ways you can make it a lot easier for yourself. 

1. Get the research done properly first. 
2. Decide on what type of VSL you are writing. 
3. Write how people actually talk. If you wouldn't say it in a conversation, don't write it. 

Tomorrow's call will be focused on how to write a BAB (Before - After - Bridge) VSL.

These VSLs are perfect for people in the pain niche, supplement niche, skincare and wellness niche - anywhere where there is a promise of a transformation. 

I will go through how to do the research, how to structure the VSL and how to write one on tomorrow's call. 

If VSLs take you a week to write, if you feel like there's something "off" about them, or if chat GPT is making your ads sound like an 1950s infomercial...

Be on the call... It will completely transform how you approach VSL writing.

*You might actually start enjoying it!* â€<This message was edited>

[19.05.25, 15:07:14] ~â€¯Jacob: Got it â€” you want to keep running Airwallex on your main funnel, while warming up Stripe on a separate funnel, both at the same time. Thatâ€™s actually a smart and low-risk approach, as long as you follow these key principles:


---

Hereâ€™s what I recommend:

1. Keep them in separate funnels

Use Funnel A with Airwallex (your main converting funnel)

Use Funnel B with Stripe (test/warm-up funnel)

Donâ€™t mix payment processors on the same funnel to avoid cross-data confusion


2. Use the same ad account only if:

Youâ€™re reusing the same pixel for both funnels (with different events like Purchase_Stripe, Purchase_Airwallex)

Youâ€™re confident in your ad structure and segmentation


> But ideally, create a separate ad account for the Stripe funnel to keep data 100% clean, especially if you're warming up with different angles, products, or avatars.



3. Stripe warm-up strategy (safe method):

Start with low-ticket offers or lead-gen + $7â€“$29 offer

Keep the first 10â€“20 transactions manual (real card usage) if possible

Slowly increase volume to 20â€“30/day after a week

Avoid subscription or rebill until the account is stable


4. Domains and branding

Use a different domain or subdomain for the Stripe funnel (not the same checkout URL as Airwallex)

Stripeâ€™s fraud detection is domain- and behavior-sensitive, so separating traffic is key



---

Why this works:

Metaâ€™s algorithm wonâ€™t get â€œconfusedâ€ if youâ€™re not mixing checkouts/pixels

Stripe will be warmed up with real user behavior, under low pressure

You reduce risk of sudden freezes that could kill your main funnel



---

If you want, I can help you create a specific Stripe-warming mini funnel (offer + structure) to run parallel to your main funnel. Just tell me your product type or niche.
[19.05.25, 15:07:28] ~â€¯Jacob: Got it â€” you want to keep running Airwallex on your main funnel, while warming up Stripe on a separate funnel, both at the same time. Thatâ€™s actually a smart and low-risk approach, as long as you follow these key principles:

[20.05.25, 16:07:14] ~â€¯David B: Hey guys. The copy call kicks off in 55 minutes. 

 I see a lot of talk about VSLs and whenever I ask what you're all needing help with, VSLs is always top of that list. 

After writing literally hundreds of them I can tell you now that MOST of the advice out there is complicated as shit. 

Writing VSLs is not hard when you know how and there are a few ways you can make it a lot easier for yourself. 

1. Get the research done properly first. 
2. Decide on what type of VSL you are writing. 
3. Write how people actually talk. If you wouldn't say it in a conversation, don't write it. 

Tomorrow's call will be focused on how to write a BAB (Before - After - Bridge) VSL.

These VSLs are perfect for people in the pain niche, supplement niche, skincare and wellness niche - anywhere where there is a promise of a transformation. 

I will go through how to do the research, how to structure the VSL and how to write one on tomorrow's call. 

If VSLs take you a week to write, if you feel like there's something "off" about them, or if chat GPT is making your ads sound like an 1950s infomercial...

Be on the call... It will completely transform how you approach VSL writing.

You might actually startÂ enjoyingÂ it!

[20.05.25, 21:06:12] ~â€¯Mikael: Anyone who can help with this? We just opened a new UK company and activated shopify payments. Now they are asking us for this? Anyone know a solution for this?
(We operate dropshipping from outside UK and our owner is not UK and does not live in UK)


Can you please describe what kind of business operations you currently have in the UK? 

Shopify has to follow regulatory and contractual obligations which require that we only provide financial services to merchants who are physically located in a supported region. Shopifyâ€™s standards for this requirement mean that registering your business in the region and obtaining a bank account is not enough.

To be eligible for Shopify Payments, you must meet one of the following criteria:

If you are a Sole Proprietor, the business owner must personally live in the country.
If you are a Company, LLC, or similar business type, you must be registered with the government of that country, and also be able to provide evidence of substantial operations physically happening there.

If you believe your business meets these requirements, please reply here with a detailed description of your operations in the UK.

Some examples of operational presence could include (but are not limited to): You rent or own warehouse space and ship your orders from there, you have an office there with employees consistently occupying the space, or you have a retail location(s) there. You may have other examples of operations you have in the country which youâ€™d like to provide: If you can respond with as much detail as possible, that is helpful for our review.

If you operate the business entirely from outside of the UK, you can confirm this also.

[26.05.25, 12:03:13] ~â€¯Miika: How do you guys do the pmax campaigns, do you exclude all other products in it or just let the main product stay?

My main campaign, has content (images etc) for 1 product but all the other products are still showing in the shopping ads in the pmax. Forgot to exclude the other products. 

Just wondering if you do 1 product per campaign when really scaling
[26.05.25, 12:35:02] ~â€¯Bony Ghadiya: Great question!

There are a couple of ways you can structure Performance Max (PMAX) campaigns â€” and it really depends on how many products you're running and what your goals are.

If you're scaling and youâ€™ve found a clear winner product, then yes â€” itâ€™s a good idea to run a dedicated PMAX campaign just for that product. That way, your creative, assets, and data signals are fully aligned with that product, and you avoid diluting performance across unrelated items.

However, if you're working with multiple products (like different collections â€” e.g. t-shirts, pants, etc.), a more effective approach is to group similar products or product categories into one PMAX campaign. PMAX is great at covering the full funnel â€” TOF, MOF, BOF â€” and when products are related, Google can use shared signals to optimize across them better.

But if your campaign is only built around one productâ€™s creative and messaging, and the rest of your catalog is showing in shopping ads, itâ€™s definitely a good idea to exclude the unrelated products. That ensures your ad messaging stays relevant and performance isnâ€™t dragged down by products that donâ€™t align with your assets.

TL;DR:
âœ… One product per PMAX = great for scaling winners
âœ… Grouped PMAX by category = efficient for broader product lines
âŒ Mixing unrelated products = can hurt performance, especially if assets are tailored to just one item

Hope this helps!

[16.06.25, 12:00:25] ~â€¯David B: Hey everyone. Hope all the dads had a great day yesterday. 

The copy call  is on tomorrow. We're going DEEP into the psychological principle of the *Belief Gap*

The Belief Gap.

Is the psychological distance between where your prospect's mind sits today and where it needs to be for them to confidently hit "buy."

If you don't close the gap, you don't sell anything.

This might be one of the most important coaching calls you get all year so make sure you're there!

See you tomorrow.

[17.06.25, 18:10:23] ~â€¯David B: In summary if people don't believe, they wont buy. 

Help them through the belief stage:

1. The problem is real, urgent, and relevant. 
2. There is a solution that is better, faster, and more effective than anything they have tried and considered trying. 
3. Your product is the best way for them to get that solution and all the alternatives are inferior. 

If people believe this, they will buy from you. â€<This message was edited>

-Access to payment processors and rates
-Maybe even legal protection (if it is harder to get sued with HK company compared to US LLC

[23.06.25, 18:18:04] ~â€¯CocowğŸ˜ˆ: â€Waiting for this message. This may take a while.
[23.06.25, 18:29:12] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: Depends ultimately what region you are selling to.

If you are selling to the US (>50%), then it makes much more sense to go with a US LLC.  Much broader set of processors and lots of flexibility and overall cheaper, better auth rates, etc.

If you are selling to the EU (>50%) for example, and you are looking for tax advantages, then HK set-up is more logical.  HK payment processors as you mentioned will be much more expensive selling cross border into the EU/ UK however and authorization rates will be much lower.

US processors want you selling to the US primarily.  This is the main disadvantage from an HK set-up.  If you sell almost entirely out of the US with a US based processor, 9/10 times you will get flagged and/or shut down.

In Hong Kong, doesnâ€™t really matter where you sell.  They are more loose from that aspect, but you will pay a lot more for it and it is less stable for payment methods like Klarna as many high risk businesses operate out of HK.

Hope that helps â€<This message was edited>
[23.06.25, 18:42:03] ~â€¯Mo: this guy do great job : https://www.fiverr.com/inbox/muhammad_osman

[23.06.25, 21:18:18] Topi: Youâ€™d train any AI by giving it resources and examples

Then afterwards checklists for quality assurance

You must write in chunks rather than ask for full production at once 

â€”

Create yourself a process something like this:

Prompt 1: Resources / high level instructions

Prompt 2: Examples

Prompt 3: Ask it to write XYZ chunk of copy following XYZ guidelines

You: stitch chunks together

You: Quality assurance

You: edit manually / by hand

â€”

I think there is bunch of material about this in skool â€<This message was edited>

[25.06.25, 15:06:48] ~â€¯L: Hey guys, do your editors source the clips themselves, or do you need to provide them?

Iâ€™m looking for someone who can build a VSL off of my voiceover .mp3

It looks like all the editor want just to glue the pieces together without doing the hard job ğŸ˜…
[25.06.25, 15:13:11] ~â€¯David B: It's a bit of both really. 

Good editors should be asking for all of your branded assets to make the VSL more effective and personalized but they should also be sourcing their own b-roll to fill in the rest of the script.

Generally, when I am writing a script, I'll create 2 columns with the script on the left and "suggested footage" on the right. This is to give them guidance on what you expect from them and so they don't have to do all the thinking. 

There are some great creative editors who can read a script and know exactly how to bring it to life but they're not usually cheap. 

Many editors are just good operators with the software and need you to provide all the materials for them.

[12.07.25, 20:14:36] ~â€¯Jacob: Quick take

Shopify Payments is a Stripe-powered â€œconnected account.â€

A suspension that hits any account tied to the same legal owner or KYC details sits in Stripeâ€™s global risk database.

Opening a fresh standalone Stripe login after a ban can trip those same risk flags and can boomerang back to Shopify Paymentsâ€”but itâ€™s not guaranteed.

Many people successfully run both Shopify Payments and a separate Stripe account in parallel, but only when neither record is on Stripeâ€™s internal blacklist. 



---

How the link really works

What	What it means	Why it matters

Shopify Payments backend	Stripe (or Bridge/PayPal, depending on country) handles processing; merchants sign the Stripe Connected Account Agreement inside the Shopify TOS. 	Stripe keeps full KYC on you (legal name, EIN, SSN/passport, IPs, device fingerprints).
Risk database	Stripe shares network-wide fraud & compliance signals across all of its properties (Radar, Connect, etc.). New merchant-risk tooling blocks â€œsuspicious accountsâ€ based on those signals. 	If you open a new Stripe account with details that match a banned profile, the system generally auto-suspends it and may re-evaluate any connected accounts (including your Shopify Payments profile).
Parallel use	Nothing in the rules stops you from adding â€œStripe (direct)â€ as an additional gateway in Shopify; guides even describe how to run both simultaneously. 	Works fine when you have a clean Stripe history. When you donâ€™t, itâ€™s roulette.



---

So, will a new Stripe login nuke Shopify Payments?

Scenario	Likely outcome

Original Stripe ban was a regulatory or high-risk-product violation (e.g., prohibited items, repeated chargebacks)	Stripeâ€™s blacklist usually flags any new account with overlapping owners. New account gets closed fast; Stripe may inform Shopify to suspend Shopify Payments.
Original ban was a paperwork/KYC mismatch but later cleared	If Stripe fully reinstated you, new accounts usually stay open and Shopify Payments is unaffected.
You create a new Stripe under a different legal entity with unique EIN, address, phone, bank, domain, and cleaned metadata	Much lower correlation risk. Still theoretically traceable (IP, device), but merchants report success.
You reuse the same entity/details	Very high probability of instant shutdown and potential ripple to Shopify Payments.



---

Practical advice for your friend

1. Appeal first â€“ A successful reinstatement on the original Stripe MID is the safest fix.


2. If you must start fresh:

Incorporate a truly separate LLC / LTD with a new EIN and bank account.

Use a clean domain, support email, and device/IP that Stripe hasnâ€™t flagged.

Expect a real underwriting reviewâ€”send invoices, supplier contracts, ID docs promptly.



3. Have fall-back gateways â€“ Add PayPal, Authorize.net, Braintree, or a high-risk PSP so youâ€™re not 100 % Stripe-dependent while things shake out.


4. Monitor Shopify Payments â€“ If Stripe asks for new docs or pauses payouts, respond inside 48 h; thatâ€™s the first sign they linked the records.


5. Document everything â€“ Keep CSV exports of payouts/orders and email threads; if Shopify Payments is frozen youâ€™ll need them for chargeback defense and proof to alternative processors.




---

Bottom line

Your theory that â€œShopify doesnâ€™t really know which Stripe merchant we areâ€ is only half-true. Shopify purposely abstracts the relationship, but Stripe still does knowâ€”and its risk engine can talk back to Shopify. If the ban was severe, spinning up a new Stripe login with identical credentials is likely to get caught and can endanger Shopify Payments. If it was a minor or resolved issue, or you launch under a clean corporate identity, the two can coexist safely.

[16.07.25, 11:25:43] Carlos Leeseman: Aimerce won't solve the issue, because your domain is likely restricted too, so simply creating custom events wonâ€™t fix it. To bypass this, you need to redirect Facebook's event tracking so they can't detect your domain.

We use Bily, which tracks events through their own domain. This lets you keep using your own domain for your store, while events are routed through theirs. It's currently the only CAPI solution we've found that consistently works when both your domain and pixel are restricted.

[26.07.25, 2:56:27] ~â€¯valentinğŸ“´: Hey everyone! ğŸ‘‹

ğŸ‘‰ Does the AI need a full 24h to adapt?

[26.07.25, 10:00:26] ~â€¯CocowğŸ˜ˆ: I donâ€™t understand the point of doing this , normally when you test a creative you launch validates headlines , adcopys etcâ€¦ 

The only thing you change is your creative to be able to isolate one variable to get clear data on your creative. 

If you want to test adcopys or headlines then you just have to copy your control creative and publish changes :) 

In any case , of the creative is really bad and you want to make some twists: 
- Not optimized as you cut the learning curve of the ad 
- â probably if the creative does not work , changing these details will not make a huge difference 
- â if your twists make the creative work then you learn nothing cause it can work just because of luck , momentum , coincidence or anything. These twists will not help you understand if what you have done made a difference. Maybe it did , maybe not , you will never know , so you could not really apply it for future creatives.

That is my vision , I prefer to get data and learn :)

[28.07.25, 20:29:34] ~â€¯Jacob: ğŸ§  SOP: Generating Image + Video Prompts with AI Based on a Prepared Script
ğŸ¯ Goal:
Transform an existing ad script into a short, high-converting video.
Each scene should last 2â€“3 seconds and include:

Image Prompt (for generating a still image)

Image-to-Video Prompt (for animating that image into short video clips)

ğŸ”¹ Step 1: Break the Script into Visual Scenes
Once you have your final voiceover script, send the AI this instruction:

ğŸ§¾ Prompt #1 to paste into the AI:
I want you to take the following voiceover script for a Meta ad and break it into a full list of visual scenes. Each scene should be 2â€“3 seconds long, and describe exactly what should be happening visually in a way that emotionally supports the script and maximizes conversion.

For each scene, include:

A timestamp range (start and end time in seconds)

The exact words from the voiceover that this scene matches

A powerful visual description that could be used to create an image later

âœ… What the AI will return:
A structured breakdown of scenes like this:

vbnet
Copy
Edit
Scene 1 (0â€“3s)  
Script: â€œYou donâ€™t need to waste hours anymoreâ€  
Visual: A woman sitting in a crowded place, looking at her watch impatiently. Harsh lighting, chaotic background, stressed expression.

Scene 2 (3â€“6s)  
Script: â€œNow thereâ€™s a smarter wayâ€  
Visual: A sleek bottle gently rotating in soft spotlight, surrounded by elegant shadows and warm tones. Cinematic lighting, modern feel.
This breakdown includes:

Timing for editing

Exact words from the voiceover

A matching visual description

ğŸ”¹ Step 2: Generate Image + Video Prompts for All Scenes at Once
Once you have the scene breakdown, use this instruction to get two prompts per scene â€” one for image generation and one for animation.

ğŸ§¾ Prompt #2 to paste into the AI:
Now take the full list of scenes you just created, and for each scene write:

Image Prompt â€“ written specifically for a 3rd-party image generator like Midjourney. It should be extremely detailed and specific, including camera type, lighting style, character description, background, and brand aesthetic. No text overlay should be included. Format must be vertical 9:16.

Video Prompt â€“ written for an image-to-video AI tool (like Runway, HaLeo AI, or Pika). Describe exactly how to animate the image: what should move, how the camera behaves, any ambient effects (e.g., steam, light rays, motion blur), duration (2â€“3 seconds), and frame rate (25fps). Do NOT re-describe the image â€“ just explain how it should move.

ğŸ§¾ What is an â€œImage-to-Video AIâ€?
This is a tool that turns static images into short animated clips.
Recommended tools:

Runway ML

HaLeo AI

Pika Labs

âœ… Example Output from the AI:
Scene 2 (3â€“6s)
Script: â€œNow thereâ€™s a smarter wayâ€

Image Prompt:
Vertical 9:16 image of a modern, premium-looking product placed on a marble surface, softly lit from above. Shot with Canon EOS R5, 50mm lens, f/1.8. Cinematic mood, warm tones, gentle glow on the product surface. Inspired by luxury skincare or tech ads. No text overlay. --ar 9:16 --v 6

Video Prompt:
Use the generated image. Animate a slow zoom-in toward the product, add soft lens flare and floating light particles in the background. Duration: 2.5 seconds at 25fps. Camera movement is steady and elegant, premium feel.

ğŸ”¹ Step 3: Image & Video Creation
Now take all the prompts the AI returned:

Paste each Image Prompt into Midjourney or another AI image generator

Once the image is ready, paste the Video Prompt into Runway, HaLeo, or similar

Download the resulting short video clips

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tip:
While some images are still rendering, begin animating the ones that are ready to save time.

ğŸ”¹ Step 4: Assembling the Final Video
Import all short clips into your video editor

Add the recorded voiceover (VO)

Match each clip to the script segment based on the timestamps from Step 1

If a clip is too long â€“ speed it up (e.g., 1.3x or 1.5x)

If a clip is too short â€“ extend it with looped frames or slow ambient effects

Sync perfectly with the spoken words

ğŸ”¹ Step 5: Polish & Export
Add the finishing touches:

Smooth transitions between scenes

Subtle visual effects (e.g., glow, blur, shine, hair movement)

On-screen captions or subtitles (if needed)

Background music or sound design

Export the final video as MP4 in 9:16 format for platforms like Instagram Reels, TikTok, or Meta Ads

[13.08.25, 16:38:08] ~â€¯Austin: Are there any major green flags you look for in a marketing strategist? Someone who's going to be overseeing your funnels and creatives?
[13.08.25, 16:46:08] Carlos Leeseman: Weâ€™re in the middle of hiring a new creative strategist, so here is what Iâ€™m doing:

Iâ€™m mainly looking for someone who thinks strategically, not just executing tasks, but actually identifying bottlenecks and figuring out what moves the needle. They should be data drivn but not data blind. Meaning they know how to interpret numbers with context and turn them into real insights. Strong creative judgment is a must, they should be able to explain clearly why something worked or didnâ€™t, and this is exactly something you can test in a trial phase. For me this is super important in order to come up with new iteration and concept ideas. 

I also really value people who improve systems. Someone who brings structure, helps track iterations, and makes the whole process more scalable.

I want someone who takes initiative, brings ideas to the table, and leads the process rather than waiting to be told what to do. Lastly, they should think beyond just the ad itself and consider how each creative fits into the bigger brand and funnel strategy. If someone has all that, itâ€™s pretty sure they are a great fit

[19.08.25, 6:21:46] ~â€¯CocowğŸ˜ˆ: We do 

1. Google form with 10 questions + approx + ask a loom video
2. â ask the expected salary (so that you get an idea of the price of the market. Ask where they live to be able to understand the differences in expected salary) 
3. Receive a good volume of people I would say 50 
4. Filter the answers and select 5 or more 
5, Do groups call with 4/5 candidates 

Goal ? Filtering and having less and less people in your funnel ğŸ¤£ And not wasting time with the ones that u know wonâ€™t fit 

No loom -> Out 
No reach your budget salary -> Out
Group call -> you are going to see by yourself that some do not fit , out 

From all of this process , you have made one or 2 interviews and you went down from 50 to 5 candidates 

Finally with this we 

1. Send a test project with 3-5 tasks 
2. â We still filter 
3. â make interview with the best candidates ( at least 2 to be able to compare) 

On all of this you made 3-5 calls maximum

Hiring full time people on upwork is achievable , but they will likely have other tasks , other upwork projects at the same time. You have to give your vision , and long term so that they feel comfortable being dedicated to you and for sure good condition

[19.09.25, 16:25:14] ~â€¯Rui Bessa: we use different structures in different ad accounts. Our usual is test in ABO, scale in ABO or CBOâ€¦But we recently started a new ad account testing in CBO(1-3-3) same concept with 3 hooks in all 3 adsets with same audience, and creatives that havent performed in abo before, start performing in this strurcture. Thats 1 CBO per concept, and its been easier to scale vertically.. At the end of the day it comes to always try different approaches while  not compromising your current one , so test different structures in different adaccounts not the in the one thats already working..

[25.09.25, 3:37:19] ~â€¯Kan: â€~â€¯Salma Jimenez added Kan
[25.09.25, 6:43:41] ~â€¯Luka: People will always be worried whether your brand is legit, and whether the product can do what it promises it does. This is our approach to building a long-term brand that we can raise funds (undecided) and exit one day. We used to get similar comments but that has dropped significantly. Ask yourself: What instantly makes you trust brands you buy from? And also basically do what the top brands do:

* *HQ Photoshoots & Video shoots* - This will instantly build trust. HQ product photography (with logo on product), HQ Lifestyle photos to use in creatives, LPs & pre-sells. Even in your carousel you can add a photo which clearly shows your logo on the label/product.
* â *Great brand visuals & designs* - High quality packaging, beautiful PDPs/LPs, emails, static ads etc. We have a full-time graphic designer and just onboarding a new one in a week.
* â *Creative Diversity* - Have HQ Studio Production ads (static+video), UGCs, testimonials, statics, regular ecom style ads, ugly ads etc. This is where building a strong creative team really matters. We hired an ex-TVC (TV Commerical) to be our lead creative strategist. 
* â *Strong Social Media* - A lot of people do check your FB/IG profile. Develop a strategy around that too. For us, we use only HQ photography with minimal text on our social media. For IG, build out proper Instagram Highlights. Can be a bunch of stuff, but the first or 2nd one ideally you want to put all the stories that youâ€™re tagged in so there is instant social proof. Then the other ones can be guarantee, how-to, value stuff, tips/quizes etc. Put yourself in the customerâ€™s perspective: what would YOU want to see? 
* â *Run More Ads* - Over time the same people will see a lot of your ads and eventually buy. Constnatly seeing your ads = builds trust.
* â *OmniChannel Approach* - Be everywhere with re-targeting. FB, Google, YT, TikTok etc. This makes your brand appear famous and everywhere.
* â *Interact with comments* - Talk with comments on a human-level so they see itâ€™s a real brand
* â *Humanize The Brand* - PDPs/LPs etc should show HUMANS. This is generally a priority for us. In the carousel we should have lifestyle photos, imagery, a ton of social proof (and not just reviews, but select reviews that show real people in them whether itâ€™s photo or video reviews)

Some others:
* Are influencers tagging you? Some people check who tagged you on IG
* â Authority ads - have authority figures in the ads.
* â Celebs or Mini-Celebs in the niche - a more expensive approach, but will instantly build trust
* â Whitelisting - re-target existing customers via whitelisting ads so they see others (from their own personal accounts) talking about your brand
* â If your product looks like all others, unless youâ€™re already the dominant player for it - work with your factory to change the design to make it more unique. Costs extra but worth it to separate your product from 999999 others of the same design. â€<This message was edited>
[25.09.25, 6:48:55] ~â€¯Luka: ^ many of these might seem logical, but I wish someone listed these out when I transitioned from dropshipping to building a real value-based brand.

One of the KEY factors was investing in studio-quality photo & video shoots. It had a big influence on building brand trust, growth, people wanting to partner with our brand and having more people share our brand.

We even had a charity we donate products to, make a video about us with the US Embassy Staff donating our products to people in need. We never asked them to, they did it by themselves.

TL:DR - Do what big brands do. Humanize the brand, HQ photos/videos, strong creative strategy, good social media presence (people check), have customers/influencers tag you, etc.

Of course these are building blocks to a brand. There are many brands that do significant numbers without doing the above. â€<This message was edited>

[29.09.25, 23:57:43] ~â€¯Jacob: ğŸ”µ Data Tab (Dynamic content)

This lets you bind elements (like headlines, prices, product names) to dynamic data sources instead of hardcoding text.
Ecommerce uses:

Personalization: Show the customerâ€™s name in a headline (â€œHey Sarah, your cart is waiting!â€).

Dynamic pricing/offers: Pull price, discount, or stock availability directly from your product data feed.

Cart/checkout info: Bind text to the customerâ€™s selected product, quantity, or bundle â€” so headlines or CTAs adapt automatically.

A/B testing hooks: Show different text based on audience segments (e.g., cold vs. warm traffic).

ğŸŸ£ Interaction Tab (Behavior & triggers)

This controls what happens when a user clicks, hovers, or leaves an element.
Ecommerce uses:

On click:

Add product to cart instantly.

Trigger upsell popups or side-cart slides.

Scroll to checkout or open a hidden guarantee/FAQ section.

On mouse over:

Show urgency (e.g., â€œğŸ”¥ Only 2 left in stock!â€).

Highlight product benefits or testimonials.

On mouse leave:

Trigger an exit-intent popup with a discount or free shipping offer.

Run JavaScript:

Fire tracking pixels (Meta, TikTok, GA4) for custom conversions.

Send events to Klaviyo/CRM (e.g., â€œStarted Checkoutâ€ or â€œHovered on Upsellâ€).

ğŸ‘‰ In short:

Data = personalization & dynamic ecommerce info.

Interaction = conversion-boosting behaviors & triggers.

Would you like me to create a list of 10 practical funnel ideas combining Data + Interaction specifically for boosting AOV (average order value) in your funnels?

[30.09.25, 7:51:54] ~â€¯Arin: Hey Austin, I used Cin7 for about 5 years until last month. I had over 1000 SKUs. Its pretty robust but it is costly. And expect price increases every year. It has more features than you will ever need so you are paying for features that you dont actually need. Integration with Shopify is great. If you use Xero as an accounting system, they work really nicely together.  But what Cin7 does, Zoho can do as well at a lower cost. Interface is also better and simpler to use. Cheaper as well and support is also better. Cin7 support sucks. Id suggest looking at Zoho before anything else. 

If you have a more simpler operation, Qoblex may also be a good option and priced really nicely. Shopify and Xero integration is decent. Support is good. Its a Norwegian business.

Hope this helps.

[3.10.25, 21:31:47] ~â€¯Santi Roa: Hey everyone!
We had a great call last Wednesday ğŸ™Œ Thanks to everyone who joined, asked questions, and shared. Weâ€™ll keep doing these calls bi-weekly, and the next one is already scheduled for October 15th â€” hope to see you there!

In case you missed it, here are some of the highlights & key takeaways from the last session:

### **Q1 â€“ Logistics & Supply Chain**

**Question:**
â€œWhen should I hire someone (like a logistics manager in China)? Iâ€™m managing suppliers, forwarders, and warehouses myself. Itâ€™s time-consuming.â€

**Your Teachings (expanded):**

* **Donâ€™t rush into full-time hires.** At early stages (e.g., \$50k/month, one hire), you donâ€™t need a dedicated supply chain manager. Focus on leverage instead of overhead.
* **Track your time.** Identify the areas that drain the most hours and start outsourcing those (e.g., video editing, support). Supply chain tasks are complex but not always worth handing off early.
* **Use sourcing agents.** Instead of a full-time hire, test sourcing agents on platforms like Upwork. Interview multiple, run a test project (e.g., source a product with sample pricing breakdowns).
* **Why sourcing agents matter:**

  * Unlock factories that donâ€™t speak English â†’ prices 30â€“50% lower.
  * Handle QC, negotiation, shipping coordination.
  * Act as your single point of contact in China.
* **Play long-term.** If you plan 1,000+ SKUs, or work with regulated/complex products (food, supplements), then consider a full-time hire. Until then, sourcing agents + SOPs will save you time and money.

ğŸ‘‰ **Lesson:** Donâ€™t outsource complexity too early. Build SOPs and test agents before adding fixed costs.

---

### **Q2 â€“ Post-Purchase Upsells & AOV**

**Question:**
â€œHow can I build better upsell flows on Shopify? Current apps are too rigid.â€

**Your Teachings (expanded):**

* **Checkout Champ = best-in-class**, but requires devs and doesnâ€™t integrate with Shopify Payments. For high-volume sellers, it can boost AOV by 30â€“50%.
* **Alternatives:** Funnelish, AfterShip, GM Pages â€” decent but limited. Test based on simplicity vs. complexity tolerance.
* **Industry shift:** Lookalikes are dead. Metaâ€™s new â€œAndromedaâ€ system favors broad targeting + creative volume. Best results now come from **creative testing and funnel design**, not micro-targeting.
* **Emerging strategy:** Quiz funnels. They convert higher because they:

  * Collect customer info through interactive questions.
  * Personalize the offer (e.g., â€œWhich type of jewelry suits your style?â€).
  * Reinforce value during the quiz â†’ smoother sales conversion.
* **Practical tip:** If upsells feel pushy, reframe them as â€œbundlesâ€ or â€œpersonalized recommendations.â€ Customers respond better.

ğŸ‘‰ **Lesson:** Donâ€™t obsess over apps. Obsess over *offers and funnel design*. Tech is just the enabler.

---

### **Q3 â€“ Work-Life Balance as a Founder**

**Question:**
â€œAt what level can I slow down and spend more time with family? Iâ€™m working 8 amâ€“10 pm every day.â€

**Your Teachings (expanded):**

* **Hours worked â‰  results.** Shared the Rockefeller vs. Carnegie example: Rockefeller worked himself to sickness, Carnegie played golf and built a \$400B fortune. Success comes from better *choices*, not just more effort.
* **Your journey:**

  * First year: 12â€“15 hours/day.
  * Then gradually set boundaries â†’ stopped Sundays, then Saturdays, then cut off at 6 PM, later 5 PM.
  * Built habits: reading daily, mentorships, delegation.
* **Efficiency unlocks freedom:**

  * Sleep better, wake earlier (5 am = distraction-free work).
  * Eliminate time wasters (social media, WhatsApp).
  * Use books like *Clockwork* to map where your hours actually go.
* **Constraints force growth.** You make better decisions when you *must* stop at 5 PM. Same for your employees.

ğŸ‘‰ **Lesson:** Balance doesnâ€™t come from â€œmaking it big.â€ It comes from designing your systems, your energy, and your boundaries.

---

### **Q4 â€“ When to Switch to a U.S. 3PL**

**Question:**
â€œWeâ€™re launching jewelry with 600 units. At what point should we move from our agent in China to a U.S. 3PL?â€

**Your Teachings (expanded):**

* **Too early to switch.** First, validate demand.
* **Step 1:** Use your agent or CJ Dropshipping-style service (even if they charge a fee). Simple, low-risk.
* **Step 2:** Once you sell consistently, then evaluate U.S. 3PLs.
* **Beware 3PL costs:** They charge for everything â†’ storage, receiving, pick/pack, tape, customer service. At high volumes, youâ€™ll need a team member just to audit invoices.
* **3PLs love jewelry.** Small/light products with few SKUs are ideal. But until you have predictable sales, stay flexible.

ğŸ‘‰ **Lesson:** Early on, speed to market > optimizing fulfillment. Move to U.S. 3PL only once volume justifies the complexity.

---

### **Q5 â€“ Role Evolution as a Founder**

**Question:**
â€œHow has your role changed over the years as your company grew?â€

**Your Teachings (expanded):**

* **Stage 1:** Did everything (dropshipping solo).
* **Stage 2:** Delegated execution (video editors, media buyers).
* **Stage 3:** Built leaders â†’ mistake: too many juniors managing juniors â†’ chaos.
* **Stage 4:** Consolidated â†’ focused on multiplying leaders, building a real management team.
* **Stage 5 (now):** Set vision, culture, long-term strategy. Talk to mentors and billion-dollar CEOs. Stay as â€œcaptain of the ship.â€
* **Frameworks you use:** EOS (*Traction*) for alignment. Long-term focus: CEOâ€™s job is not â€œdo tasks,â€ but **raise company valuation by aligning vision + multiplying people.**

ğŸ‘‰ **Lesson:** As CEO, your job evolves from â€œoperatorâ€ â†’ â€œmultiplierâ€ â†’ â€œvisionary.â€ If youâ€™re still in the weeds, your ship risks going in circles.

---

### **Q6 â€“ Breakthrough Ideas from Employees**

**Question:**
â€œMy marketing employee executes well, but big ideas donâ€™t come from her. Should I always be the one driving creativity?â€

**Your Teachings (expanded):**

* **Big ideas can come from anyone.** Examples: Google Maps, 3M Post-it Notes, Disney innovations â€” all came from employees, not founders.
* **Motivation > equity.** You donâ€™t have to give equity for employees to innovate. You can:

  * Pay well.
  * Provide mentorships/training.
  * Expose them to higher-level thinking (events, trips, workshops).
* **But be realistic:**

  * The team that gets you \$0 â†’ \$1M isnâ€™t always the team that gets you \$1M â†’ \$10M.
  * Some employees wonâ€™t evolve into senior roles â†’ youâ€™ll need to upgrade talent.
* **Practical next steps:**

  * Clarify what you expect (campaign ideas? new channels? product launches?).
  * Set KPIs.
  * Complement juniors with experienced hires or mentors.

ğŸ‘‰ **Lesson:** Employees *can* innovate, but only if you create the environment, clarity, and incentives for it. Otherwise, founders will remain the main source of vision.

---

# âš¡ Closing Thought

Your teachings boiled down to this:

* **Think long-term.** Build systems and culture, not just products.
* **Leverage smartly.** Outsource, delegate, and hire with intention.
* **Stay the captain.** CEOâ€™s job is to set vision and multiply people, not get lost in execution.
* **Balance life.** Work boundaries arenâ€™t luxuries â€” theyâ€™re constraints that force you and your team to grow smarter.

[21.10.25, 12:00:23] ~â€¯David B: Deals I've seen performing well

You can also run opt-in emails to your list to get "early access" to BF and CM deals.

[11.11.25, 21:27:18] ~â€¯Jacob: there is a lot of models...- you can also offer him a model if you dont like it and think what's the best for you -

here are few examples

A fixed monthly base for stability.

Plus, a management fee based on a percentage of the Amazon ad budget they manage (e.g., 5-10% of ad spend).

Works well when you want them to increase ad spend responsibly.

Inspired by general PPC pricing models. 
Click Click Bang Bang
+1

Base salary + bonus on revenue growth

Fixed base salary.

Bonus kicks in when overall sales/revenue via Amazon ads grow by X% compared to previous period.

Aligns their work with real business growth, not just clicks or spend.

Base salary + bonus on ROAS / ACOS targets

Fixed base.

Bonus when they achieve defined targets: e.g., ACOS (Advertising Cost of Sale) drops below 25â€‰% or ROAS (Return on Ad Spend) exceeds 4Ã—.

Good for focusing on profitability rather than just volume.

Revenue-share model (without big base)

Lower or minimal base salary.

They receive a share of actual incremental revenue generated by their Amazon PPC campaigns (for example 2-5% of incremental revenue above baseline).

High upside for them, higher risk for them, but strong alignment.

Flat monthly management fee + performance bonus

You pay a fixed monthly fee for all the Amazon PPC management services.

Then an additional bonus when KPIs are met or exceeded (e.g., new product launches, hitting 1M USD in ad revenue).

Provides predictability + upside.

Milestone payments

Define key milestones: e.g., launch new ASINs, get X reviews, hit Y ad impressions, reduce ACOS by Z%.

Pay bonus each time a milestone is reached.

Good when the role includes key project-based deliverables, not just ongoing operations.

Tiered bonus structure

Base salary.

Bonus levels tied to tier performance: e.g., if ad spend = $500k/year â†’ bonus $5k; $1m/year â†’ bonus $10k; $2m/year â†’ bonus $20k.

Motivates them to move up tiers, not just hit one level and stop.

Profit share / EBITDA share

They get a fixed salary + a share of the net profit (or contribution from the PPC campaigns) after costs.

This model emphasises cost efficiency and focuses on real business profit, not just revenue.

Use when you trust your tracking and can isolate the PPC campaignsâ€™ contribution.

Hybrid model: Base + % ad spend + bonus on KPIs

Combine multiple levers: moderate base salary, management fee based on ad spend, and bonus if KPIs like ACOS, ROAS, AOV (Average Order Value) are met.

Gives stability + scalability + performance orientation.

Long-term incentive / equity / retention bonus

For key PPC managers (especially strategic ones), include long-term incentives: for example, after 12 months of growth you get X% stake in new product line, or a retention bonus if certain multi-year targets achieved.

Good for locking in talent and aligning long-term interests.

[25.11.25, 23:35:27] ~â€¯John B: How many visitors do you guys wait to reach when split testing price to make a decision?
[25.11.25, 23:38:19] Topi: Generally speaking any A/B tests you wanna run like 500 orders and 7 days at least, this has been serving me well

With small rapid decisions you end up turning off losing stuff at some point and then its really pain in the ass backtracking where the mistake was possibly made while performance tanks
[25.11.25, 23:38:58] Topi: Crazy fluctations and sudden spikes on variant A/B is a real thing and often what is leading by far in the beginning actually ends up losing
[25.11.25, 23:40:35] Topi: If youre running so little traffic you cannot get 500 orders in 7 days, just turn your new price fully live and see what happens. 

If you get instantly more profitable and offer scales, amazing

If nothing happens or bad results, just turn back old price
[25.11.25, 23:43:44] ~â€¯MG Business: What offers have been working well so far in Q4 for you all? Iâ€™ve been running simple bundles, Black Friday/christmas obviously, and also seeing success with sending free downloadable pdfâ€™s with their purchase â€<This message was edited>
[26.11.25, 0:33:02] ~â€¯David: yeah man especially on BF. We got our target ROAS and CPR, I got 4 different ad sets and surfscale them up or down accordingly. Lets say our target CPR is 10, if I see its at 8 I surfscale 20-25% every 2 hours. If it goes above 10 I let the algo develop a little bit because sometimes it takes time and the CPR drops naturally. If its staying above for too long: surfscale down slowly and most importantly introduce new Ads especially on BF/CM. For us it stabilzes quickly and we usually can scale up again the next day.
[26.11.25, 0:40:49] ~â€¯Mathias Bo: Got it are there different ads per adset, or is it 4 times the Same adset ? 

And is there a scenario, where you Double down the Budget ? â€<This message was edited>
[26.11.25, 1:41:13] ~â€¯David: There are different tactics out there but we split it in: 

- Best Vids
- â Best Pics
- â Best Carousels
- â Dedicated BF Ads (all formats)

Approx 10-15 Ads per Ad set, weakest ones get replaced for new ones. 

Interestingly, the metrics get better for all Ad Sets when we scale, not just the BF one. BF is where 50%+ of our budget goes but we can also surfscale the normal ads. 

This is perfect because after BF we can simply deactivate the BF Ad Sets without interrupting learning / performance of the other ones too much. 

We definitely double up in the beginning when we got low spend and an Ad Set is performing really well. Doubling down was never necessary because after time you get a feel for if you should give it more time or if itâ€™s definitely too much spend for the current ads and can preemptively surfscale down. This way you donâ€™t mess up the algorithm too much.  

If your metrics are off by 300%+ already you can definitely scale down faster though to not burn money. Definitely take a look at the ads though, often introducing new / better Ads for a new targeting group can all the sudden reduce CPR and allow scaling.

[30.11.25, 0:03:17] ~â€¯Cocow: Then to find , I think here some have probably nice processes :) 

On our side, we send to upwork in fact but you can do meta ads or LinkedIn ads to a form

Then , you filter the form because you asked specific questions 

Then you do a group call with top 5/6 , 

Then you do 1:1 with the best 2/3 or less

Goal : filter fast , reduce time consumption and put people in the same call you will see the one that speaks too much , the one that cannot communicate good , the one who is shy but smart , etc â€¦

And if you can do it for example video editors , hire 2 at same time , so that if one quits you have the other one , and he can train the next one for example 

That is what we have been doing , not saying best approach :)

Copyright infringement

Image misuse

Or Brand misuse (passing off)

[1.12.25, 7:57:23] ~â€¯Kim Romanov: You'd be wise to register that trademark ASAP, or someone else might beat you to it. We've been down that road before, and trust me, it's a whole lot easier to register initially than to deal with the hassle of suing someone later on.
[1.12.25, 8:15:37] ~â€¯Adam Ashe: 1. Go to Amazon.co.uk/report/infringement
2. Start a report
3. Enter "the product numberâ€
4. Tick all, select "Other IP Infringement" in report type
5. Brand , "your brand "
6. IP being asserted "Unauthorised use of our brand name and product identity (passing off / brand impersonation)"
7. More information :

"The listings in question are using our brand name â€œyour brandâ€ and copying our packaging design, product name, and marketing description without permission.

â€œOur brandâ€ is a genuine, established brand actively trading via our official website â€œyour websiteâ€ . The infringing listing misleads customers into believing it is affiliated with our brand when it is not.

This constitutes unauthorised use of our brand name and product identity (brand impersonation / passing off).

Please remove or suspend this listing and prevent the sellers from using our brand name.

8. If it allows you to, attach screenshots of their listings and a screenshot of it on your website
9. Fill out all your contact info. Make sure to use the email address thats tied to your amazon account
10. Rights Owner
11. Seller on Amazon - Yes
12. Submit
[1.12.25, 8:15:53] ~â€¯Adam Ashe: Had to do this last week. This worked within 5 days it was removed

[2.12.25, 21:49:57] ~â€¯Oscar: Hey guys, what do you do again when Claude is just giving you the same angles, structure in the copy's for video ads, advertorials etc?

i have a project with all sorts of documents in it of the market, audience etc. 

in the prompt i write:

Hey, write me a script for a generic video ad.

Situation:
	â€¢	U.S. single-member LLC, treated as a disregarded entity
	â€¢	I live outside the U.S. (currently tax resident in the UAE)
	â€¢	No U.S. office/warehouse/employees/agents
	â€¢	Inventory/fulfillment is outside the U.S. (primarily China)
	â€¢	Weâ€™re registered for sales tax in 30+ states (economic nexus)

What I was advised before:
Iâ€™ve had multiple consultations over time, including with James Baker, CPA (well-known in e-commerce tax), Chris Rivera, plus another accountant, and the consistent view was:
	â€¢	If thereâ€™s no U.S. trade or business / no ECI, then thereâ€™s no U.S. federal income tax at the owner level (Iâ€™d pay tax in my country of tax residency instead).
	â€¢	I was also told that even using Amazon FBA (including inventory stored at Amazon warehouses) does not automatically create ECI, because I donâ€™t have direct access to or control over Amazonâ€™s warehouses (the facilities are owned/operated by Amazon).

What changed / the issue:
A new accountant is now saying I do have Effectively Connected Income (ECI) and therefore owe U.S. federal tax this year because:
	â€¢	I collect/pay sales tax in 30+ states, and/or
	â€¢	I do business with U.S. customers through a U.S. LLC, so â€œthat aloneâ€ creates ECI.

Additional fact:
The only operational change vs last year is that at the end of December we moved some inventory toward Amazon/FBA, but we havenâ€™t started selling/fulfilling from FBA yet â€” launch planned around Jan 1.

Questions for the group:
	1.	Has anyone here been told that sales tax registrations/economic nexus alone creates ECI / U.S. trade or business for a nonresident owner of a disregarded LLC?
	2.	For those using FBA as a nonresident, did your CPA/attorney treat inventory in Amazon warehouses as creating ECI/USTB, or not? What was the reasoning?
	3.	If you were challenged on ECI, what specific facts did the IRS/your advisors focus on (inventory ownership/location, fulfillment, agents, importer of record, title passage, etc.)?
	4.	Any recommended CPAs/attorneys who are truly solid on nonresident e-commerce + ECI?

[29.12.25, 4:23:49] ~â€¯Asad: Sales tax and income tax are separate concepts.

Collecting sales tax in U.S. states does not automatically mean you owe U.S. federal income tax.

For non U.S. owners, U.S. income tax is driven by where the business actually operates. This typically depends on where inventory is located, where orders are fulfilled from, and when sales activity begins. It is not determined solely by having U.S. customers or a U.S. LLC.

Amazon FBA is the primary area to watch. Once inventory in U.S. warehouses is actively fulfilling orders, U.S. tax exposure can begin. Timing is important. Inventory that has not yet started fulfilling sales is often treated differently.

I would ask each advisor to point to the specific case law or precedent they are relying on so you can understand how they are reaching their conclusion.
[29.12.25, 4:28:26] ~â€¯Asad: I pretty much align with James and Chris on this one since there is a timing difference between inventory being moved to FBA and actual fulfillment happening after the tax year. But always good to have reference on precedence and case law on how each advisor reached their conclusions.

[1.01.26, 23:54:48] ~â€¯David: Whenever you pool different formats (Pics, Vids, Carousels, this new dynamic feature where you can mix it even inside the ad) results will be inconsistent. Because meta priorities videos always (as long as they arenâ€™t ultra bad).

[7.01.26, 14:19:18] ~â€¯Steph: ğŸš€ Quick Google Ads win we just wrapped up at More Than Scaling

We took one of our own internal owned brands from ~$300/day â†’ $75k/day in 58 days using only Google Ads.

No FB. No TikTok. Just clean structure + execution.

What moved the needle:
* Geo-based campaign segmentation (US/CA focus)
* Aggressive PMax + feed-only setups
* Product variant testing inside Shopping
* Demand Gen + remarketing layered properly

End result: $1.2M revenue, ~4x ROAS.
